She lay completely still. It was almost dark; only a single oil lamp cast its feeble glow through the room. She was cold, even though it was a very warm evening. The women had just left, and a half-dozen mutilated servants had carried the large tub away. In the air and on her skin lingered a slightly soapy scent of roses and saffron, which could have been delightful. Her body had been thoroughly washed, shaved, anointed, and perfumed. What a ridiculousness that she was cleaned just to be soiled again right after.

For he would come to her again today: she had only been in the palace for a few days. As long as his ardor lasted, he came every evening to his latest wife, it was said. Until he wanted the next one and discarded the previous one among the others.

Most families that received the message - rather the command - from the Sultan to give him their daughter in marriage bowed down, perhaps feeling it was an honor. But not all; and her kin, led by her mother, had not complied. A brave, strong woman who had known what awaited her daughter and had wanted to spare her such a fate. Especially since a wedding with a lover was imminent. It had done no good, but a family and this time even a fiancé had been accused of a despicable offense, and for their resistance had to pay with their lives.

It was hard to believe that as a little girl she had envied the women of the Sultan. For the lavish, days-long wedding celebrations, for example. Or when a palanquin glided through the streets as if it had floated out of a fairy tale, surrounded by an incomprehensible fragrance of rose petals and gentle spices. She had imagined being cared for by dozens of willing hands. There had been no golden cage or groping fingers in her childish thoughts.

He would have bathed as well, would be perfumed with the scent of fiery spices, which nevertheless could not conceal his true filth. He never wasted much time. He would throw off his garment, pull down her blanket, and roughly knead her breasts for a moment. Then he would push his powerful belly against her and shove her legs aside. If they did not obey immediately, clumsy hands would help with brute force, and he would take possession of her. Well, he would believe he was taking possession of her, as only such a man might think. But he would never possess her; her innermost self remained hers.

After each time, she had to think of her lover with tears of pain and sorrow in her eyes and of the only secret time when he had been able to come to her. As clueless as they had been, as awkward the hands of young people must have been, they had touched each other so tenderly and sensitively, so lovingly, later passionately and impetuously. She had willingly let him in - what could happen, just a few days before the wedding? It had been unexpected, a little frightening. And wonderful. Quickly, their kisses had to stifle the sounds of both.

She shuddered and pulled the thin blanket tighter around herself at the thought of what nightmare it had now become. And she could count herself lucky that the Sultan had not noticed that he was by no means the first. The days and nights since the pompous wedding had passed like behind a veil of dull horror. But the day before yesterday morning, she had woken up with a completely clear mind and had known what to do.

After a short time above her, he would start grunting like one of the wild boars from the forests. The smell of his sweat would invade her nose. And although it would be the mild, fresh scent of an outwardly clean body, she would feel covered in animalistic stench when the little streams sprang from his sides and his heated belly and laid a slippery film over her body. Then, all of a sudden, it would be over. Almost.

She had thought everything through carefully. With two fingers of her right hand, she would feel for the right ribs beneath the leathery bulges on his back. Yesterday she had tried it; with some pressure, it worked. He would take her firm grip for the excitement that the other women had advised her to feign, and would grin foolishly and self-satisfied. He truly believed he was providing pleasure! As soon as he lay exhausted on her, she could take the stolen knife from the kitchen - it was already under the pillow - and stab it through his heart from behind her fingers. And when she had rolled him off her, it would graciously take her own life as well.

The door opened, and a beam of light fell into the room. A moment later, a shapeless silhouette darkened the light.

Angelliese, oh Angelliese, what have you done? You lavish me with beautiful samples from Rasasi and El Nabil, and I fear I won't be able to sleep peacefully without one or the other from the collection. However, the Sultan won't keep me awake anymore, as it will be arriving at my place tomorrow. A quick decision that I surely won't regret after wearing it enthusiastically three times.

What kind of magic water is this that captivates me so? Musc Sultan starts with a surprise that you wouldn't necessarily expect given the fragrance notes listed above: a wonderfully fresh, juicy lemon opening that doesn't come across as ethereal-light like a cologne, but somehow thicker, more substantial... I don't know how to express it. This so-called "meaty" lemon gradually becomes sweeter, accompanied by a lovely, delicate rose that forms a very harmonious connection with the lemon. This is soon complemented by spicy-sweet saffron, which increasingly takes the lead in the fragrance journey. A very successful, balanced composition for my nose.

Only after about an hour does the namesake musk begin to emerge more prominently, initially in a well-balanced interplay with the spicy saffron, then infused with more woody notes. For a while, the musk even takes on a slightly animalistic direction until it finally develops into the musk that I love so much: warm, soft, trustworthy, sensual.

Who would have thought? A truly high-quality smelling perfume without a hint of cheap synthetic notes, an exciting, versatile fragrance development, very good longevity, strong sillage up to the rather skin-close musky finale... and all of this for under €20 for 50 ml - what more could one want?

At first, I perceive floral notes. Initially, I think of carnation, but then Tiaré crystallizes: very floral, radiant, with a hint of a fruity note. A delicate fruity sweetness also dances around my nose for a brief moment. Oh dear! My usual three spritzes are way too much; I'm almost crossing the line into a headache. Vanilla pod and vanilla absolute have made my eyes shine and caused me to push away the voice from my subconscious: Monoï?! There was something, and it wasn't good...?! Coconut body oil "Monoï Tiaré" bought many, many years ago and used once. For me, it’s an overwhelming, radiant, all-consuming, crushing floral scent. How could I have suppressed that so much?

Additionally, I don't perceive any vanilla at all, really nothing. It remains Tiaré and nothing else. It becomes weaker over time and slowly more bearable, but that doesn't change much for me. Mostly, I am just annoyed with myself.

The poor rating is partly due to my perception of this flower, but also to the fact that I can't detect anything vanilla-like even in the drydown.

So, Monoï Tiaré enthusiasts: You will find what you’re looking for here.

Addendum: Here too, it is stated: 95% of the ingredients are of natural origin.

It’s an autumn day, I open the package and there it is:
a beautiful bottle, well crafted, but what I’m even more excited about is the content. I spray it on and there it is ...really beautifully fresh, amazing!
What I smell are lemon, mandarin, simply wonderful. It is very fresh but not intrusive, nothing piercing, which I don’t like. I wait... this pleasant freshness remains, what I notice later is the apple that comes in. Hours later I still smell it... a pleasant very soft freshness and a very light woody note.
I believe it has become my new favorite scent :)

review_title: The Fascination of Light Anise Opening New Worlds
review_content:
This was a blind purchase.

It was such that my nose did not want to leave the wrist.
It’s like a high...
The fascination of opening new worlds within me and my perception...
New galaxies ...
An explosion of everything ...

The beginning starts with this wonderful raspberry with a hint of lemon in the background.
Right after that, anise combines with the creamy note, which develops very softly and almost balsamically warm.
Then the light, not overpowering vanilla with a minimal touch of warm and slightly green benzoin that also feels balsamic. And then the bright, light wood.
The entire progression of the notes is balsamic, warm, very rounded, light, and not intrusive.
Since my skin softens many sweet to extremely sweet fragrance notes and transforms many notes into a slightly bitter tone, I also did not have a carnival experience with this one!!!

The Pool Boy came by today with greetings from Xyrena.
I think he was on a Dark Ride before and got quite wet there...

He slathered a load of sunscreen on his skin and laid out in the sun with a bowl of flavored candies.

He's quite nice, but I hope he doesn't stay too long.

So many brands trying to market the next big thing as "a masculine rose" this and that.. in my very personal and humble opinion this has already been done in the past and this fragrance is one of very few of them. The first time I smelled it, so many years ago, I had a medicinal feel from it and despite having acquired it only recently it has been growing on me secretly over these years. I happened that not so long ago I tried it again in the store and I was baffled by how good was the aroma I was getting: fresh leather, still a little of that medicinal undertone and very light smoke, then it popped into my mind so clearly: this openness, this breeze is coming from a rose accord! Of course I should have noticed it earlier but back in the day I knew rose was there and it just blended in like in many woody orientals, let's call them this way. Too bad on my skin the rose shines too much, and therefore I wish to test the "flankers" (arabie, maroc etc..) to see if they lean even more into that perfect middle ground this is already very close to.

review_title: Of Roses, Woods, Smoke, and Spices
review_content:
Whether it smelled like this or something similar in ancient Alexandria is up for debate. However, this fragrance does have quite a bit of "old exotic" about it.
First and foremost, there are the spicy rose scents that play the leading role with their aroma. Surrounded by numerous ornaments of balsamic, smoky, and woody elements. And as for the "old exotic": La Fumeé Alexandrie largely avoids "modern" ingredients like aldehydes, molecular building blocks, and cashmeran or similar.
From what I know about the now seriously regarded aromatherapy, primarily natural and nature-identical fragrance substances can have a significant positive influence on body, mind, and soul. What the "artificial" ones can either not do at all or only to a limited extent.
It is no coincidence that rose scent is a fragrance of calmness and confidence. It has the ability, in whatever way, to "smooth the waves" in times of inner unrest or fear.
In combination with "grounding" scents like balsams and woods, this effect can be further enhanced.
And with spices like vanilla and cinnamon, gentleness and mindfulness are conveyed. So much for the aromatherapeutic applications.
Possible conclusion: Perhaps such fragrance compositions help, especially in critical times like these, to convey a bit of self-confidence, mindfulness, and comfort in a natural way. When looking at the history of perfume over several centuries (or the last approximately 100 years), it somehow stands out that during and after times of crisis, certain fragrance combinations were the most used. And in "carefree" times, characteristically different ones.
For me, at least, Fumee Alexandrie is a wonderful and imaginative "soul comforter."

review_title: A Last Rose in the October Sun
review_content:
I tested this perfume in autumn 2015 at London Heathrow Airport - it was on my way home from a business trip in the UK. From the very first moment, I was absolutely thrilled! But back then, I didn't want to just shell out over 200 pounds... But now, to my luck, there was sharing!

You all know those days: late October, sometimes even into early November with a late frost, when the sun shows its full strength one last time. Golden, warm light falls on colorful leaves and also on one or two last roses. Not a dark rose, no, a rather small, blood-red rose. That is the impression this perfume gives me. And it also reminds me with its smoky-spicy notes that soon the foggy, dreary days will come, the time for fireplace fires, mulled wine stalls, and also for Christmas baking. As a confessed autumn fan, I can find something beautiful in every phase of autumn.

A floral-smoky-woody-spicy scent that is hard to surpass in its beauty!

Oud Dhul Q is a distillation of organic, plantation-grown Thai oud wood and a batch of incense-grade Cambodi wood. In other words, a mixture of farmed and wild wood. It is very much related to Aroha Kyaku but far smokier, woodier, and darker in tone. It is also one of the most enjoyable Ensar ouds I have had the pleasure of trying, and the one I can realistically imagine owning myself one day. (Of course, it will probably have been sold out by the time I get around to buying it.)

Up top, there is a long, drawn-out smoke note, fused with aged oud wood, tobacco, and the bright saltiness of ambergris. But there is also a labdanum-style thickness and sweetness behind the opening. This smells like burned toffee mixed with liquid tar and leather. The smoke and tobacco place Oud Dhul Q in the same general arena as Aroha Kyaku, but smelled side by side, clear differences emerge. Oud Dhul Q leans towards the saline side of the flavor wheel, while Aroha Kyaku’s cherry leather makes it both sweeter and brighter. Yet, in Dhul Q, there is clearly something thick and syrupy at play behind the opening bouquet of smoke. This syrupy density is as salty-bitter as molasses, chestnut honey, or even labdanum itself.

There are no cherries or fruit in the heart, just a buttery leather smeared with tar and honey as seen through the fiery blaze of campfire smoke. The Heathcliff of pure oud oils, Dhul Q is a smoky, saturnine beauty that demonstrates that oud oil can be as complex and as ‘perfumey’ as a Chanel extrait. Its haunting umami quality makes me think of kinam wood kept in Japanese vaults, an image that persists in jumping to mind even though I have never been within five hundred kilometers of either Japan or a piece of kinam agarwood.

Oud Dhul Q is a typical smoky-incensy Oud that initially strongly reminds of "Aroha Kyaku | Ensar Oud / Oriscent" (AK).
Only this one has a deeper and darker soul.
Overall, this Oud presents itself more complexly. The "vegetable" side that AK has is completely absent here and is now overshadowed by the smoke and incense.

In general, the smoky components have been even more amplified and pushed to the forefront compared to AK.
It also has a slightly metallic quality, with sparkling incense flashing through from time to time. It is leathery as well.
One might think it is black leather treated with birch tar.

Nevertheless, this oil feels quite young. You can tell it was distilled only recently, as this oil still feels very "sorted." There is only black and white here. No brown tones, no green tones... only black and white. Black sparkling resins, black earth, and white smoke. Not the smoke of a fire, but rather a vapor of incense and other smoldering materials.

A better Aroha Kyaku! If you love smoky Ouds, then this one is a must-try.

Many thanks to Rhombus for the sample!! :)

All fragrances from the Carolina Herrera brand are potential candidates for purchase for me. One of my absolute favorite brands. Besides the 212 line, I also love the CH line. This Sport was a spontaneous blind buy, as I found it for under 30 euros for 100ml. Even though the fragrance pyramid didn't completely convince me, I didn't have to think long and added this scent to some others in my cart.

I have owned this CH Men Sport for a few months now. The bottle is very stylish and impresses across the board. The entire CH line, including the women's line, is very elegant in terms of the bottle and really fits well with the high-quality fragrances of this line.
The first test was rather modest. Unspectacular and interchangeable. Back then, I gave this fragrance a 7.0. In the meantime, I have upgraded it to 8.5. I have worn or tested it several times, and the more often I wore it, the more interesting it became for me. There are such fragrances that you have to wear more often until you like them.
First of all, regarding the Sport addition: Despite its freshness, I find it unsuitable for sports. What characterizes sport fragrances for me is a non-intrusive and simple freshness. For that, it is clearly too spicy for me. Which fragrances one wants to wear during sports should be left to each individual and not dictated by a name. Those who have no issues with spice while exercising can certainly wear this well. For me, it is a good daytime fragrance like Sauvage, Bleu de Chanel, and the like.

About the scent: It starts fresh with bergamot, grapefruit, and sage. The pepper note is very present immediately after spraying. A strong but not too intrusive pepper note that fits really well with the fresh notes. The fresh sage has a slightly cucumber-like quality, which may not appeal to everyone. I really like this note as it stands out from others. Maritime notes follow and give it a nice lightness in contrast to the pepper. These maritime notes are more in the background, as the spice stands beautifully in the foreground. Over time, it becomes softer, but it retains its beautiful spiciness. It doesn't have the CH DNA at all.
The performance is also very good. The sillage is really strong with the beautiful spiciness, and the longevity is also adequate.
The creation is an acquired taste and may not appeal to everyone. It probably wasn't a bestseller, as this fragrance has been discontinued. Nevertheless, it is still well available for a small price. Those looking for a fresh-spicy scent might find it here. For the price, I can really recommend it.

review_title: Freshly Showered and Quickly Prepared Gazpacho and Vegetable Stew
review_content:
This scent doesn't seem to be particularly well-received here, yet I want to defend it.

As a fan of Herrera for men, I naturally explored the rest of the label, although nothing could compare to the original.

212 is too poppy, Chic a bit sweet, CH Men and Men Privé too overwhelming…

Therefore, the statements suggesting that CH Men Sport dances a bit outside of the CH Men line and actually has little to do with it caught my interest.

Peppery notes were mentioned, as well as the association with cucumber salad… And that it is not a pure sport fragrance in the sense of being very citrusy or aquatic. Interesting enough to give it a test, especially in the hope of finding a pleasing all-rounder that offers something special and isn’t worn by everyone.

At an airport, CH Men Sport then managed to stand out in a skin test against other candidates, so I had to seize the opportunity with the currently low prices (obviously a discontinued model) and a good offer from a nice perfumer.

The bottle is solid and heavy, with a good finely distributing spray unit and is covered on one side with sturdy canvas fabric. Tactilely very nice and also somewhat retro in appearance - I quite like its design clarity. The scent is blue-purple, but it could also have a green tone, which I would have found more fitting.

So how is it? It starts relatively fresh-peppery and maintains that throughout. There isn’t a great development, which is an important criterion for many. However, I do appreciate a linear development.

Associations with pepper, cucumber, subtle hints of freshly cut vegetables like celery or fennel (or should I just say dill) and a prominent sage note emerge. Overall, this creates a salty-fresh-spicy impression for me, so thoughts of a cucumber salad with pepper are indeed not far-fetched. However, it doesn’t repel me; rather, I quite like it.
Everything is fitted in a masculine way, without resorting to overtly masculine brute notes and without the ubiquitous "consumer-desired" sweet rounding.

Perhaps CH Men Sport is not an artistic revelation, but I was looking for a fresh all-rounder that doesn’t polarize too much and still has its own character. One must also admit to some light shower gel associations, but more in a wellness-fresh way, just as cucumber and pepper have made their way into this segment in recent years, e.g., with Kneipp.
This doesn’t necessarily have to be a killer argument for an all-rounder; even with Sander For Men, a non-sweet, spicy all-rounder, this "freshly showered" comparison is often made. I see CH Men Sport in a very similar role and purpose, although its finish has a lighter, fresher spiciness rather than the strong, darker one.

As a discontinued model, for me it is a very affordable, somewhat quirky, fresh-peppery all-rounder for everyday use. Whether it will be missed when it’s gone, that remains to be seen… Just as it will be seen how people will cope with the vegetable touch…

review_title: When Carolina Wants to Do Something for the Figure!
review_content:
Carolina Herrera, a great name, and in her younger years, the lady was also very pleasant to look at. She is now 77, but still quite lively. With her now several fragrances from different scent lines, she has made a big name for herself among insiders, but the big breakthrough has so far eluded her. Thus, she is usually found somewhere between mainstream and niche, and always good for a surprise. Her perfumes, all produced by Puig, appeal to different target groups, so she is overall very well positioned.

From the CH Men fragrance line, there is (or was) also a sporty variant, visually clearly distinguishable from the regular black one, the red/white faux leather-decorated bottle really jumps out at you. It definitely makes a lot of visual noise and makes you curious whether it can be as loud as it looks, and of course how far it is from the original, quite sweet CH Men.

For me personally, there is absolutely no connection between the two fragrances, apart from the similar bottle. The scent starts directly and with full force, bergamot and grapefruit give a rather short guest appearance, at least here you can sense a bit of the sport, then the heart note comes in mercilessly. The marine notes provide a cool, fresh bed for the pepper. The Sichuan pepper really hits hard, and with such enormous pepper notes, I always struggle a bit, as within a very short time my entire receptors are occupied and I can hardly smell anything else. Similar to the pepper note of the new Dior Sauvage, this one is too, only thankfully it doesn't have that character of pickled pepper, but is much fresher, almost cold and slightly metallic. I am still not a fan of too much pepper in perfumes, yet I have somewhat come to terms with it. Because if you "survive" this point, you are rewarded with a wonderful base. Vetiver and sandalwood give the previously very cold scent a slight warmth, leaving an unusual but quite interesting feeling. The longevity is fantastic; thanks to the pepper, I had a solid 8 hours of it, and it wasn't completely gone even then.

The most interesting aspect is probably the price. I got it through a sharing, but the 100ml bottle for under 30 euros is not a purchase that hurts, and for that, you get a stable, non-everyday sporty scent that stands out clearly from other representatives of the genre. Still, I find the designation "sport" somewhat inappropriate; purely from the feeling and nature of the scent, something more along the lines of power, energy, or something similar would fit better. Because power has been packed in here quite well, dear Carolina. If she does sports like this or has done so in the past, then hats off!

There can be no talk of "sport" here, I agree with my predecessors on that. This "CH/HC" is fresh like an April breeze, which we could really use right now to make the heat a bit more bearable.
And it has a bit of a "rack" to it, like cotton towels that have been dried outside in the fresh air (which I really like...), WITHOUT fabric softener. In particular, the sage takes the lead here. Crushed leaves of this versatile plant blend with an Icelandic sea breeze that blows in cool and refreshing.
From a beach covered in juniper, there’s a complimentary scent greeting.
Grasses and reeds sway in the cool wind while rain clouds bring showers.
Woody-earthy aromas waft from trees and soil.
I find this EdT excellent for the warm season.
It has good longevity and its projection is (at least for me) quite intense (around 8), although a lower sillage is indicated at the top.
However, this is not intrusive, but rather pleasant to sniff this "April freshness."

review_title: Not much fragrance, despite many oils... rather strange.
review_content:
This is a difficult one. I don't find this perfume particularly musky at all. Nor is it strong on floral tones. OK for gents, not for ladies.

There is a mild oriental & woody aroma after a while, but this is a weak perfume and needs constant topping-up to maintain any strength at all. Disappointing, but I guess Al Haramain can't hit the bull's eye every time. The 35ml size cost less than US$6, standard bottle in the signature flip-top Al Haramain cigarette box.

This is the very first time that I look at the "Smell Similar" list and I think it is 100% correct... it turns out that people are not always affected by olfactory hallucinations!

I currently own Layton, Red Tobacco and I used to have Bottled Elixir too (but I found out that I don't love patchouli bombs)... and I agree on the listed similarities.
Bottled Absolu is essentially a combination of Layton with Red Tobacco's dominant note.

I've tried it recently, and I would say that if you don't own any of the 3 frags I listed above, you could easily purchase Bottled Absolu (for a reasonable price) and make the other 3 redundant.
As I already have Layton and Red Tobacco, Bottled Absolu is not for me but it is definitely full bottle worthy.

Performance wise, I would agree with what most of the people are saying here, noting at least 3+ hours of decent arm's length projection. Given its notes, this is more of an autumn/winter fragrance which would be best used in the evening.
Usually, I steer away from blunt seasonal categorisations, but the tobacco note used here would make it suicidal if used during hotter months.

WOW, this is really good. Hugo Boss has a real winner here. Funny thing is, I tested Bottled Elixir around the same time I tested Sauvage Elixir. Liked the Sauvage better and bought it. Boss Absolu is so much better than the Boss Elixir, I definitely want it too.

Very nice, smooth almost creamy well blended combo of notes. Incense is there, but not overpowering. If you don't like strong incense, still test Absolu since the incense only makes up part of the whole. Very masculine fragrance. Performance is nuclear. I woke up the next day to whiffs and during my morning cardio it started to project again. This was about 20 hours after the initial sprays. I'm getting a full bottle of this baby. Test, don't blind buy.

Seeing all the hype and all the comments saying that this is Hugo Boss' best fragrance yet made it clear that I had to get my nose on it as soon as possible. But when I finally got to smell it, I wasn't as surprised as I expected to be. I left the hype give me way too big expectations for it.

That doesn't mean that I don't like it. On the contrary, I'm seriously thinking on acquiring a full bottle. The opening comes off as quite spicy, with the warm leather and the smoky frankincense accords being indeed the most prominent. Soon enough, the patchouli gets through, and so does the myrrh which turns Boss Bottled Absolu into a delightful blend of spiciness, leather, incense, and sweetness, none really being too overpowering. There's a resinous undertone too, which adds depth to the composition. It's a beautiful blend which instantly reminded me of Boss Bottled Elixir, which also shares the patchouli and frankincense notes. Not only those, but cedarwood is also shared by the two perfumes, which pushes through once the perfume/s settles down with a dry woodiness. At this point, you can still feel the leather and frankincense, but it's all made a little bit more herbal and warm with the help of the davana note, while the cedarwood compliments it nicely by adding a certain dryness and slight woody feel (but not too strong, though). The smokiness is also slowly overpowered by the sweetness, yet it never truly leaves, maintaining a dark, sophisticated aura. For whatever reason, Boss Bottled Absolu smells slightly familiar to me, even though I haven't previously owned any Hugo Boss fragrances (apart from a few samples). And that made it a bit less unique to my nose, even though I still find it to be a very soothing and sophisticated scent, perfect for dressed-up events.

Then comes the performance, which was pretty good. After about 5-6 hours, the fragrance settled down quite close to my skin; still detectable, though. For the first two-three hours, the fragrance had very good projection; 2-3 feet. It then started to calm down substantially, tricking me that it had already become a skin scent. But after I asked some friends if they could still smell it, they said they did, and from about a feet and a half away. So I suppose I was just going nose-blind to it. So I'm very pleased with the overall performance here. 3-5 sprays seems the sweet spot.

So in summary, yes, this is one of Hugo Boss' best fragrances ever. It's warm, leathery, smoky, sophisticated, mature... the perfect wearing experience for a wedding or a professional/work event. It's borderline niche-smelling stuff, kept at bay and slightly more mass-appealing thanks to the sweetness. So after all, would I buy Boss Bottled Absolu? Maybe. This is a fragrance well-worth your time and interest, especially if you like aromatic-first fragrances with a nice dose of leather towards the ending. But do try it first; blind buying is not really an option with these kind of fragrances.

Overall Rating: 8.2/10

Right upon the first spray, this fragrance takes me on a journey. Straight back to my childhood.

Back when life was easy.
You could eat vanilla icecream without caring about your weight, or your cowmilk allergies.

When you rode a bike and the chain fell off, you’d put it back with your bare hands without caring about the grease all over your hands and clothes.

Talking about grease, I loved John Travolta and his leather jacket in that movie Grease. Boy do I love the smell of leather.. not too much.. just a whiff of that coolness.

Sorry where was I? Ah yes this new Boss Bottled. Phew it’s quite something.

review_title: The designer version of Shaghaf Oud Azraq
review_content:
I'm usually not a fan of Boss fragrances—I generally find them to be somewhere between bland+basic and drugstore trash. But this one is the first that I actually like! Woody-balsamic, sweet, and leathery—wow! When I first sprayed it, it felt oddly familiar, and after reading other opinions, I realized: Shaghaf Oud Azraq EAU DE PARFUM !

Comparison:

- ShOA offers a wonderfully realistic honeyed sweetness, while BBA has a honey-like, balsamic-amber sweetness—I’d guess it’s fir balsam, complemented by a good dose of ethyl maltol.
- ShOA has a dry oud accord, while BBA rests on a balsamic-woody base, with a substantial dose of some superamber (Amber Xtreme?).
- The light cinnamon note in ShOA seems to have been replaced with incense in BBA.
- Leathery notes and patchouli are about equally strong in both fragrances.
- BBA has a noticeably more intense scent; however, I find that ShOA has significantly better sillage, even though the scent itself isn’t as strong. In terms of longevity, ShOA also clearly outperforms BBA.

For me, ShOA is the niche version of BBA, or rather, BBA is the designer version of ShOA. ShOA remains a 9.5/10 for me, but for a Boss fragrance, I still find BBA really good!

BBA also has a certain harsh fruity note that reminds me of Layton, especially on the Drydown.

Fragrance Notes: Top Notes: Incense, Leather . Mid Notes: Patchouli, Myrrh. Base Notes: Cedarwood, Davana. Fragrance Review First thoughts, it's a powering leather, smoky, amber and woody fragrance. • This fragrance gives off an intense smoky leather vibe, best suited for the colder months and definitely a hit or miss for most people. This is not versatile. • The mid...

First I hated it. Mainly because the leather accord can smell really weird and a bit disgusting to my nose under some circumstances. But as long as the leather is not doing anything weird and I smell it from some distance and not directly from my skin, the scent is absolutely amazing. Especially the Myrrh / Patchouli Combo with this candy like sweetness is quite addicting...

Review method : Test spray 2 different times from 2 different stores. The first time I tested this on my arm, I liked it a LOT. I thought it smelled masculine and bold, and like a classier more woody Gaultier offering. I had vanilla, heavy incense, light cinnamon, and sticky notes and it lasted forever. Today I went to a different location and tried it again on my fist....

This is a 10/10, bare with me though. The weather is 73 daytime/night time wearing casual clothes doing casual things a 5/10. The weather is 69 degrees and night time wearing a leather jacket, peacoat, or dressed your best doing cool shit, this is a 10/10. It has to fit a mood for you and others to enjoy. The sillage is mediocre (3-5 ft in the wind), the longevity is mediocre...

review_title: I genuinely don't know what to say
review_content:
It smells like the balls of a deer that has been two-footed in the face by a donkey. Genuinely stink and it reeks everywhere.

Have to give them credit for how smell it gets, just a little spritz and you're in for a really long day. I can't get rid of it and it overpowers anything that dares to come close to it.

The alpha male fragrance.

review_title: Took this one from my husband
review_content:
As soon as my husband had me smell the paper at the store, I knew that I would end up taking his bottle.
On my husband, this is a sad, weird, spicy - woody - boozy thing indistinguishable from several of his other colognes. His skin does something strange to patchouli.
On me, Boss Bottled Absolu is spiced caramely sweetness with smokey incense that peeks through and keeps it from being too sweet. Once it dries down, the notes meld beautifully, taking turns rising to the top and keeping me from going nose blind to it all day.
I easily get 8 hours longevity from this with 1 or 2 sprays. I don't like scents to project beyond a couple of feet and I find the projection on this one isn't crazy.

I think the title says it all, in my humble opinion, this was by far the best designer release of 2024. Niche quality, excellent performance, decent price. This is dark brooding symphony: vanilla, frankincense incense, benzoin, leather, wood, patchouli. Some of my favorite notes are present. It opens with a dark resinous incense monotone and slowly develops into a deep leathery amber. In the dry down you, you will get a striking dark macerated patchouli leaf which emulates a dry tobacco leaf. There are shades of a few PDM favorites in there: Carlisle, Layton, Layton Exclusif and shades of Herod all come to mind.

Longevity is exceptional for a designer release, easily pushing over 12 hours on my skin, revitalized every time a gust of cold air rushes across my skin, with very strong projection and Sillage well into the 6th hour.

Due to the heavy nature of this composition, it only really works on the cold of Autumn and Summer. There are many frags in my collection that I would consider safe for date nights in the warmer months, in air conditioned spaces, I think this one would be pushing it when applied in any kind of humidity or mild weather. I would only wear this in the cold.

I tend to classify most frags as unisex, typically leaning either more masculine or feminine, but I think this one is out of the unisex camp and into masculine territory, but I could also see a certain kind of woman pulling this off.

This is honestly a masterpiece in my opinion, it's very rare to find a designer fragrance that has such strong attributes and densely composed notes. If I smelled this one without any frame of reference, I would be hard pressed at the thought of it not being a niche frags, let alone a release from a house that has mostly flown under the radar for the last two decades. I tried the Bottled Elixir recently that this is purported to be a flanker of and they are definitely similar.

This, to my nose, is a more user-friendly version of Laudano Nero, which has recently become a favorite of mine. I would say it could be a down market version of LN or an upscale version of Mauboussin Star for Men.

I would give this an 89/100
High art at a mid-range price.

I was out at a fragrance store testing fragrances. Tried many boss fragrances but none was catching my attention. of course there wasn't a tester for this one so I took the decision to get a sample from a kind souk partner. I'm happy that I did because I'm thinking now to buy a flacon. At the start its a bit aggressive and overwhelming but after 5 minutes it was amazing. Spicy woody notes are ruling and there is a sweetness too but not so strong as I thought. Leather is at the background but very hard to notice. As it dry's down you get more woody notes and the leather is starting to show up but in a shy way. It is there but its so well blended that you cant notice any raw leather sense at all. a very pleasant smell and surprise for me. I'm pretty new at exploring the world of fragrances but I believe its well executed very well blended and the raw materials are amazing. Amazing quality for amazing price in my opinion, good work on this one Boss.

I hope this was helpful and if you have any questions feel free to ask and I will try to answer them if I can ^^.

I absolutely love Bottled Absolu. I’m not a big Boss anything fan till I tested this piece out. My only problem with it is that I cannot wear this all the time living in SoCal where it’s hot. Just during our short winters and occasionally at night Spring and Fall.

I have Layton and I put this up there with it! Beautiful fragrance that is complex and develops nicely.

review_title: Great fragrance, I was pleasently surprised!
review_content: Fell in love with it the first time I smelled it in a store. I really like this scent, but I don't use it a lot. I think it is a fragrance for very specific occasions, more formal. Amazing performance and projection! It has a powerful and mysterious vibe to it. The incense note is very prominent, which I enjoy. Would 100% buy it again.

review_title: Interesting but can't figure out where to wear it
review_content:
The smell itself, the opening, is harsh but that part does go away. What is left is this smooth leathery ambery sweet (smoky(?), incensey(?)) smell.

I like it, but I wish it wasn't so strong because it sticks all day, then all night, then on your clothes in the morning and you wish it was just gone. I wish the totality of this fragrance mellowed out more than it does, it lasts forever and is strong as heck. I'm probably more picky than others on longevity and would prefer a scent to be mostly all gone by bed. This is off 2-3 sprays MAX on each arm and one on the chest.

The other main thing I have, this isn't an easy grab. I'm not really sure what places I could wear this too, maybe a night out with the boys, a semi-casual work lunch, annnnnd...? date night I'd rather something less intense and more seductive, during the day I'd usually go to a more milder scent.

A quintessential person & vibe on this would be a dude wearing plaid going out for beers kinda vibe. If you are into this type of thing, the fragrance is a beast, but to me personally, a bit overhyped to my tastes as a not-quite middle aged guy.

Boss Bottled Absolu ist wie ein Herbstspaziergang in einem edlen Wald, wo die Luft von reifen Äpfeln und würzigen Hölzern erfüllt ist. Ein Duft, der die Wärme eines schalenden Kaminfeuers einfängt und mit Noten von Zimt und sanftem Moschus abgerundet wird. Es ist wie das Gefühl eines feinen Kaschmerschals auf der Haut—weich, aber mit Charakter. Absolu ist nicht nur ein Duft, es ist eine Einladung, in einem Moment voller Eleganz und Tiefe zu verweilen, leicht süß und doch kräftig.

Ayant fait mes débuts avec Boss Bottled EDT, la plupart des versions arrivées derrière m'ont déçues. Mais alors la version Absolu, n'ayant aucun rapport avec le reste des versions, est un chef d'oeuvre pour l'hiver.

Ce côté élégant, un cuir très caractériel mais pas écoeurant (il s'agit d'une de mes seules références qui possède du cuir, je ne suis pas cuir à l'origine).

Un sillage extrêmement fort, faîtes attention à ne pas trop en mettre non plus (très puissant). Une tenue monstrueuse (+8h sur peau), tout ça pour dire que je passerai mon second hiver avec ce parfum pour toutes mes occasions !

J'ai l'impression que depuis quelques années les maisons populaires ont compris l'interet commercial de sortir des parfums nichés.

On voit ainsi un dior sauvage qui se veut de base frais et vert sortir une version elixir cuirée et boisée, aux antipodes de l'idée de départ.

Je pourrais citer a-men, le male, et tous les parfums qui se déclinent à l'infini. C'est un raccourci qui je trouve porte un peu préjudice aux jus originels. Dommage.

Très bon parfum, la n'est pas la question

So riecht ein wahrer Mann, hat Ähnlichkeiten zum Carlisle und zum Triumph of Bacchus geht aber gewissermaßen seinen eigenen Weg, durch den Weihrauch und das Sandelholz sehr edel sehr dunkel und doch hat es etwas weiches an sich. Kann ihn nur empfehlen als alternative zum Carlisle da dieser auch gleich lange hält und natürlich wesentlich preiswerter ist.

This is a warm-spicy fragrance with a hint of sweetness, yet it has this dark aura that is so simple and pleasant to wear.

At the first spray, I thought: Is that Oud? Because it has, at least in the first 1-2 minutes on my skin, something animalistic, which quickly faded away.
And then I smell this dark leather coated with incense - warm and balsamic, as well as the myrrh in here.
It is a dark, dry, and mysterious scent, which is also contributed to by patchouli, bringing a bit of earthiness with it. The sweetness in this fragrance comes from the Davana - which seems floral and delicious.
I also get tobacco vibes here, as it is so warm and spicy. It’s not listed, but I just get those vibes from it. Otherwise, it has a rather linear scent profile, which only becomes a bit softer/woodier in the dry down.

Overall, it smells like a gloomy, spicy, ambered aura, enveloped in gentle wafts of incense, resting on light woods. This perfume definitely has the potential to pass as a niche fragrance. Longevity and sillage are good for me: 8-9 hours were really top on my skin.

review_title: The best, the final boss, the ultimate challenge!
review_content:
Good morning, friends of refined fragrance sports.

I had more than enough time to test the Hugo Boss Bottled Absolu, and it's not for nothing that I say he is the final boss!

Never before has the brand managed to create such a brilliant, masculine - striking, and intense scent that is even more than convincing.

It really knocked my socks off when I first wore it with 3 sprays on my neck.

This mixture of a Layton (even though the apple note is missing) and a light Red Tobacco is truly more than successful.

In the opening, you immediately get this intense, warming, and soothing sensation on the skin.

In the drydown, not much changes; the fragrance just wants to stand out positively.
The spiciness increases a bit and is pleasing

Incredibly beautiful, attractive, and sexy!

Fragrance clear 10/10
Longevity also definitely very long, hence also 10 points

Sillage is also out of this world; never has a Hugo Boss fragrance managed to project so much, also 10/10

The bottle is typical Bottled, just in a different color, but valuable.
Conclusion: The new flagship from Hugo Boss is, in my opinion, even on par with great, renowned niche fragrances and definitely does not need to hide behind them!

It can do something - and it does it really damn well!

Boss Bottled Absolu by Hugo Boss is a masterpiece. I bought it blindly and I was shocked by this wonderful fragrance composition.
I didn't expect such a leathery/woody scent cloud with an intense incense aroma. I love this perfume and it is addictive. The sillage is also absolutely amazing; you will definitely be noticed with it. Very masculine and a true surprise from the House of Boss. I can only recommend it and I am happy to have it in my collection.

Boss Bottled is an endless series. Completely milked out, a few flankers hit the market every year. Even though this series is extreme, that's the business in the designer world. It can be a bit tiring when you constantly test loveless flankers and are already slightly annoyed. However, there are also true treasures among them, which can also be said about this newer Absolu. Since I ordered a sample, I was able to test it. Even though we are currently heading towards summer and sunshine: the next autumn and winter will surely come. Moreover, such sweet-spicy fragrances always work well in the evening. Here you really get a great noble scent that shines best in the evening and can also work quite well in everyday life during autumn and winter temperatures. The listed similar fragrances really match: "Carlisle | Parfums de Marly," "Layton | Parfums de Marly," "Shaghaf Oud Azraq (Eau de Parfum) | Swiss Arabian," and to some extent "Red Tobacco | Mancera," although this Absolu is significantly softer. In short, one could say that this Absolu is a blend of Layton & Carlisle. Definitely also independent and great if you don't want to invest in those extreme niche prices.

In terms of price, this new Absolu is not as cheap as many designers. Affordable, but perhaps the price will drop when it gets older. Available in 50, 100, and 200ml. For €80 for 100ml, you can get this, which is already quite good.
The bottle is the usual Bottled, but here in a special color combination. It looks quite elegant and perfectly captures the DNA of this noble evening scent.
The scent starts off really well. It could easily pass as a niche fragrance in a blind test. Right after spraying, it reminds you of Carlisle and has a slightly soft note like Layton. A great sweet-spicy mix that smells thoroughly noble and, thanks to the high patchouli content, has some dark elements, making it a top-notch evening fragrance. This slightly fruity Davana note also smells really good and is present in the top note. Additionally, there's an extremely pleasing leather note. You don't have to be a leather fan to like this combination. The myrrh spice is very appealing and convincing. A great combination of sweet spice, leather, and also cedarwood that is present throughout the entire development. A harmonious creation with a sweet-woody dry-down. Overall, this Absolu is absolutely worth it. It smells high-quality and is already a bargain at this price.
Performance is also top-notch, lasting around 10-12 hours with really good sillage in the first hours. Even later, the scent remains very active, and you have fun with it.

Overall, a great evening fragrance that can be worn all year round, especially when the sun has already set. A wonderful sweet-spicy scent like Carlisle with a great portion of mysterious patchouli.

To keep it short: I can only recommend it.

I just bought it recently, as I was convinced by all the positive reviews and ratings everywhere, and ultimately decided to get it.
I sprayed it on during a test (around 7:00 PM) and was immediately convinced by the intense sillage. I could still strongly perceive the scent all evening until I went to bed. At some point in the middle of the night (around 4:00 AM), I woke up and immediately noticed how Boss Bottled Absolu was STILL projecting incredibly strongly from my hand.
Even the next day at 10:00 AM, I could still perceive the scent very well, even though fragrances tend not to last that long on my skin.

About the scent in general: At first, it was a bit too piercing and too sweet for me. However, this changes quickly, and in the drydown, I can't get enough of it. I like it much better then.

I was really convinced. Great scent for the upcoming winter.

The Elixir as the current highlight of the Boss Bottled flankers and a standout of last year, I didn't think Boss could top it - I was absolutely wrong!

The scent begins with an intense leather note, accompanied by incense - at first, it already seems animalistic. As the fragrance develops, the earthy and balsamic notes of patchouli and myrrh increasingly come to the fore, giving the scent a dark depth and complexity. This is rounded off with davana and cedarwood, which provide a warm-woody and slightly sweet base. Even though it is not listed, I can still detect a brilliant apple note that remarkably resembles that of Layton Exclusif. Dark, oriental, masculine; that was the Elixir already - but the Absolu combines all of this in an even more complex, higher quality, and brilliant way.

I see the longevity similarly to the Elixir, but here it adds even more to the projection. One of the best releases of the last few years!

Boss Bottled was truly a fragrance worn by many in the late 90s and early 00s. I also received a small bottle as a gift and wore it from time to time. Back then, however, my passion for perfumes was not as developed as it is today. Over the years, the scent faded more and more from my consciousness, as there were many new and exciting discoveries in the world of perfumes. The fragrances from Boss eventually became less interesting and appealing.

This changed in 2023 when Boss launched the Bottled Elixir. Inspired by the Elixir hype that Dior started with Sauvage, which I really like, I had to give this scent a try, and it convinced me right away. Significantly less mainstream than the current designer lineup, it is dark, spicy, smoky, woody, and has a minimal touch of old school, similar to Sauvage Elixir. However, the original Bottled DNA was not recognizable here. Rather, it was a new, independent fragrance.

Now comes the next release from Boss with the Bottled Absolu. This continues the positive trend set by the Bottled Elixir. Again, there is no similarity to the original DNA. In terms of depth, wood, and spiciness, it goes in a very similar direction as the Elixir. However, there is a greater presence of sweetness. If I had to summarize it briefly, I would describe it as: amber-dried fruits in balsamic resin, with a spicy and smoky note and a woody base. The scent feels very well balanced. Nothing is too much or too little.

The longevity is absolutely positive. 8 - 10 hours are easily achievable. The sillage is also noticeably present in the first 2 - 3 hours, and then pulls back a bit closer to the body.

I also think I detect a slight hint of tobacco in the fragrance, but that might also be due to the combination of the notes used, as it is not listed. If I were to compare the scent, fragrances like Carlisle by Parfumes de Marley or Red Tobacco by Mancera come to mind right away. Not that it smells exactly like them, but for me, it definitely goes in the same direction as the mentioned fragrances. However, I do not perceive the listed leather.

In general, one can say that the fragrance does not do anything groundbreaking, but for a scent from the designer segment, it can really hold its own. The trend is clearly moving, as with the Elixir, towards niche and away from the designer uniformity. If the Elixir is a bit too edgy and rough for you, you might find the Absolu to be a more wearable scent that still radiates that certain something. I feel it will be better received by the masses due to the stronger sweetness than the Elixir, which I would prefer slightly over the Absolu because of its edges and very light freshness.

In conclusion, Boss has done everything right here again and, compared to many other designers, has dared to take some risks with the releases, which is a very positive development. I am definitely curious to see what comes next. Keep it up, Boss! ;)

review_title: Lucky Grab with a Blind Purchase
review_content: After a long break from perfumes, I stumbled upon Boss Bottled Absolu here in the forum and spontaneously bought it blind in a 200 ml bottle during a sale. From the moment I placed the order until it arrived at home, I questioned the blind purchase multiple times, but fortunately, the risk paid off for me. The scent is pleasantly warm and spicy. It lasts extremely long,...

review_title: Absolu puts the other Boss Bottleds in the shade
review_content: When I noticed in the store that there was a new Boss Bottled, I had no great expectations and almost jokingly took it off the shelf. When I sprayed it on my skin, I had to double-check if it really came from a Boss bottle. I am usually accustomed to synthetic scents from Hugo Boss, but this fragrance is indescribably soft and pleasant to the nose. Then I realized that I knew...

What can I say... I was standing there... in front of the doctor's office - I was a bit bored, as I had 20 minutes until my appointment. So I quickly went into the Müller next door to sniff some perfume.

The Boss Bottled series had never been anything for me!
That's why I hadn't even had the newer flanker "Absolu" on my (fragrance) radar!

But then this coincidence happened, and it made me grab the (test) bottle solely because of its beautiful dark color. My nose wanted to wave it off beforehand - but I did it anyway (thankfully).

When I sprayed it on the test strip and the scent reached my olfactory bulb, I must have looked like someone who just found out that Michael Jackson is still alive.

I was immediately captivated and had to first smell the usual coffee beans. But even after that, this unbelievably good scent was still present.

This fragrance is like a spicy, leathery, smoky adventure. I did not expect something like this!
I don't know of any directly comparable perfume. Maybe it has a certain touch of PdM-Layton. But definitely no clone or anything similar. A standalone fragrance that almost leans towards niche.

However, this strong presence has to be liked. Blind buying is therefore not recommended.
But it's easy to test in any city.

H/S is also not bad! Both are above average.

Everyone in my circle has expressed themselves absolutely POSITIVELY about it!
And indeed - they thought more in the direction of niche than designer. No one suspected Boss behind it.
For example: My buddy Franky wears Boss (The Scent for Him) as his signature. He guessed Layton Exclusif.

To continue the story - I then ran excitedly to the saleswoman with the words "Wooo where is the Boss Bottled Absolu??!" - Immediate response: "Unfortunately, that's no longer available!" "But it's ordered!"

I then walked towards the doctor's office while my disappointment was still filling me and dragged this unbelievably interesting scent behind me (I had sprayed it again just to be safe).
As I sat in the waiting room, I actually received a wink from the receptionist with the words "great scent."

At that exact moment, I decided "I must get the Absolu TODAY!".

That very evening, I drove 11 kilometers to the nearest "large perfumery" to buy this scent. I have not regretted it for a second.

Therefore, I would recommend the following to every fragrance enthusiast:

Definitely try it out!!!

…. sprayed in the drugstore….. immediately thought I know this so well, damn it. At home, I sniffed "Al Awsaaf | Lattafa / لطافة" and "Ameer Al Oudh Intense Oud | Lattafa / لطافة". Yes, a blend of both comes, at least in the opening, quite close. I layered those two last winter…. that must be where the memory comes from. However, Boss clearly has a different...

As a woman, I can only say "YUMMY" smells unbelievably good!

We had a sample of it and it blew me away.
Such a masculine sweet slightly smoky scent, I didn't expect that from Boss.
I love heavy sweet fragrances like A*Men or Tobacco Vanille EAU DE PARFUM on my husband and was really totally surprised.
Actually, his collection is complete, but this sexy perfume will definitely be purchased!

Irresistible!

Today I finally had the opportunity to test this 2024 hype fragrance in a perfumery. Does it live up to the hype? After almost 2 hours, I can clearly say: YES! It starts extremely leathery and smoky, with the frankincense apparently serving only as an enhancer for the leather note and not being as distinctly perceivable as, for example, in This Is Him!....

The Boss Bottled Absolu is very underrated; I hardly see anyone talking about the scent. I received a sample and tested it, and I must say that I like it so much that I am considering getting it as my first Boss fragrance since I really like the Boss Bottled line. The scent starts off leathery; I find the leather note really nice, and with the incense, it becomes even more beautiful. Although I hate leather in perfumes, I find the leather here really lovely as it is not too overpowering but still present. The scent becomes more pleasant and settles down a bit.

The longevity was very good for me; it lasted all day. After about 7-8 hours, it is still there but not as strong, fading more into the background. The next day, that is today, I can still smell it, but only very faintly.

The bottle is really beautiful; I like the bottles from the Boss Bottled line, and especially with this one, the color is really nice.

review_title: WOW, is this supposed to be a designer fragrance?
review_content:
Who would have thought that a Boss scent could excite me again after I dove into the world of niche fragrances? Don't get me wrong, some designer fragrances, like Armani Code (2024) EAU DE PARFUM or Bleu de Chanel Parfum (and a few others), still accompany me often because on some days I just want a straightforward scent around me.

But this Boss release really surprised me. It is not the "typical" designer fragrance, but it's also not absolute niche. But let's be honest, the boundaries often blur anyway. Whether this is due to a trained nose or whether many niche fragrances are taking a more mass-market approach is another question.

I can't help but compare "Boss Bottled Absolu | Hugo Boss," at least in principle, with Dior Homme Parfum (2014) (God bless it and please forgive the crazies selling it at completely inflated prices here).
What both fragrances share in my perception is this really beautiful dark and masculine leather. While the implementation in Dior Homme Parfum (2014) was sometimes a bit more challenging and I often wondered what occasion I should actually wear the scent for, that is not the case with the Boss at all.

Here you get this deep, dark leather and also a very intense incense. Both notes can quickly become challenging because they can be very dominant.
These notes are also dominant here, and I find it remarkable how harmoniously the scent has been composed as a whole. I can't claim that I can distinctly smell Davana or cedarwood here, but they obviously manage to round the fragrance off beautifully.

I am thrilled. It's amazing what you get for your money here.
Anyone who likes leather fragrances and isn't completely averse to incense must definitely give this scent a chance.

review_title: Top, but definitely not blind-buy material
review_content:
I really like Boss Bottled Absolu… absolutely!

With the classic Bottled DNA, Absolu has pretty much nothing to do; instead, you get a dark, intense scent that feels like it lasts forever.

The similarity to Layton doesn't quite resonate with me, as Layton tends to go in a "fruity" direction with the apple and lavender notes; I do see the resemblance to Carlisle more, although there the patchouli note comes through much stronger in my opinion.
To me, Absolu smells extremely well-balanced, with something reminiscent of dark chocolate and spices in the result.

When you consider that 50ml are sometimes priced at €60 at Douglas and similar stores, one might almost think about ordering Absolu just to try it. However, I would rather advise against that and suggest testing the scent first (it's available everywhere).
The intensity and the scent profile will certainly not appeal to everyone, and especially in the office, school, etc., Absolu runs the risk of becoming quite overpowering if you apply more than 3 sprays.

In conclusion: Aside from the classic EdT/EdP, it is undoubtedly my favorite in the line, but still better to test it first, then buy ;)

This Boss is not a normal designer fragrance. The scent experience is much more complex and interesting. When I smelled it for the first time, I was immediately thrilled! From Hugo Boss? Frankincense, leather, cedarwood You get exactly that! I think this scent is simply MEGA! Wearing the fragrance, you receive a warm scent curtain in front of your nose that caresses it like...

I believe the thirty-second positive review of this fragrance is no surprise anymore. Nevertheless, I would like to briefly share my own two cents with a pinch of experience.

Boss Bottled Absolu is a powerhouse on every level. For me, it's a niche fragrance, packaged and sold in designer clothing. Dark, mysterious, present. Not classic designer synthetic, but pure, genuinely enjoyable fun. Although it took me about half an hour to fully get my bearings after the first spray, I now love the scent very much. Especially since the price for what is offered is more than pleasant.

I found the comparison to Layton interesting; I hadn't come across it until recently. Now that I have smelled it, I think: Yes, there is a strong similarity. Absolu is for me Layton, but with slightly less sweetness and darker. Of course, it's not a 1:1 comparison, but the basic DNA is present in both, and I find that somehow cool. I do think I would prefer Layton due to its increased versatility; however, considering the price, Absolu definitely remains the choice.

Longevity/sillage are fantastic. Almost too strong: 2 sprays, and I was approached multiple times about what a strong perfume I was wearing today. This can be good or bad depending on the situation.

Season? Cold. I'm not someone who assigns fragrances to seasons, but wearing this in the height of summer could count as public indecency.

So I love the scent, as you can surely read, and I will definitely get a second bottle as soon as mine is empty. Even if nothing from Boss has wowed you so far, you must try Absolu; it's a hidden gem. :)

review_title: This is a declaration of war!!!
review_content: It is loud and clearly challenges the entire niche. And yes, it has what it takes. Finally, the designers have realized that they also need to be loud and oriental, and that's exactly how the fragrance starts. The first impression was simply: Wow, and this comes from a designer. You have pure animalic here. You have leather and incense that together remind me of the "cow...

review_title: Married to the Elixir, but having an affair with the Absolu
review_content:
I really don't like incense and patchouli, not at all. But fragrance notes like these guarantee a strong presence. When I smelled the Elixir, I found it intense, reminiscent of Sauvage Elixir, I liked it, sprayed on clothes and skin, let it settle, great scent. I hesitated to buy it, why? No idea. A year goes by, Bottled Elixir is still on the list. I saw the Bottled Absolue at the local perfumery, with (in poor light) an identical bottle. Applied it and fell in love. The Elixir is sweet, somehow more charming, you like having it around. Incense mixed with leather, an absolute room-filler and it has been lasting on my jacket for 2 weeks. Again and again a hint of Bottled Absolue in my nose, simply wonderful. Absolutely recommended for those who enjoy sweet and spicy scents.

I'm sorry Elixir, but I love your little sweet brother... It's me, not you!

What can I say about this fragrance, except Wow! In my opinion, the best flanker since the discontinued Boss Bottled Intense! This fragrance is a concentrated dose of attractiveness and spice in a bottle! A very successful dark, warm scent for the colder days. Beautifully leathery, woody, and sweet. A very pleasant and almost addictive combination. With this fragrance,...

review_title: "I'm not that kind of person, honestly!"
review_content:
When I heard this sentence, or something similar, from a date during my single days, all alarm bells would ring for me, and I would internally conclude the matter. "They all say that," I thought to myself. Maybe this woman really isn't that kind of person, even if her first appearance suggests otherwise.

However, I neither have the time nor the desire to be convinced otherwise. The first impression counts, after all.

I recently experienced something similar in the perfume store while searching for a new autumn or winter scent. By chance, I spotted a new flanker of Boss Bottled.

"How many are there now?" I thought. "Definitely 10." I quickly checked Parfumo and could hardly believe my eyes. There are exactly 30!

Another one... nobody needs that?! Since sniffing fragrances is less time-consuming and, above all, less nerve-wracking than dating, I simply sprayed the new Boss Bottled Absolu on a paper strip. And then I was shocked.

From the very first second, I perceive a very potent, woody, sweet-spicy scent. "This smells more niche than many niche fragrances," I think to myself. I have to keep smelling it and toss the other test strips away immediately so I don't get confused.

I like it more and more and it reminds me a bit of "Red Tobacco | Mancera," whose DNA I truly love, although I find it not very suitable for everyday wear and a bit too playful. The Boss Bottled Absolu smells grown-up, masculine, and serious compared to Red Tobacco. Less sweet, yet the scent is clearly spicy-sweet and strongly leans towards Parfums de Marly.

I usually can't pick out the individual notes, but anyone who enjoys fragrances with a spicy incense DNA will surely find this appealing. And wow, it's really strong! Longevity and sillage are above average and justify the slightly higher price in my opinion.

"I’m not that kind of person, honestly!" I hear the new Absolu saying among the 29 other Boss Bottled flankers. And this time, the statement is even true, because the scent is really different from its relatives and deserves its own, individual name to stand out from the crowd.

One of the best and most interesting scents for the cold season this year. Give it a chance.

This is my first review and I will keep it brief. I had read a lot about Boss Bottled, watched numerous videos. And yet, when I first experienced it, I was blown away. The mix of (light) apple, cinnamon, and this perfect vanilla in the drydown is quite unusual for a designer fragrance. I never perceived the older versions of this line like this, but Boss Bottled...

review_title: Like Layton but darker. And cheaper.
review_content:
This Boss also has the classic Boss DNA, of course: If you really don't like it, there's no need to read further.

For those who are not averse to it, a truly interesting new touch develops from the familiar DNA. It increasingly reminds me of Layton (without being a full-fledged dupe), which smells good but is way too expensive. At the same time, it is darker, more suited for evenings than casual wear, and more autumn/winter than summer.

In my opinion, it could be a tad less sweet and/or synthetic, but many popular fragrances are too sweet or synthetic for me as well, so don't let that deter you.

Since the price is much lower compared to its original, it earns a few extra points.

The longevity was surprisingly good! I could still smell it after 12 hours!

Feel free to give it a try.

Very good opening with a lot of oriental spice and an alcoholic base. The scent character of the very strong opening remains, only the intensity decreases to a more approachable, pleasant, muted level. At the same time, it also becomes slightly sweeter. Nevertheless, Boss Bottled Absolu remains a clear men's fragrance.

I really like this opening, both in terms of performance and pure scent. It is definitely a men's fragrance with incredible longevity. Furthermore, one clearly gets the impression of a niche perfume.
Important: You have to dare to wear this perfume, as it is not accessible to everyone's nose. But that is not what Boss Bottled Absolu wants, and that's a good thing.

I received a sample of Boss Bottled Absolu and tested it blind.

I approached it completely without expectations and was quite surprised.

At the top, it was super strong leather, which I really liked. However, I perceived the incense a bit as a flaw. Maybe it's just not for me. The sillage was already extreme; I didn't smell anything else at first.

In the drydown, it becomes quite close to the skin and noticeably milder. Nicely woody, very pleasant.

For the price, it's an absolute steal! I can highly recommend it.

review_title: Where Does Niche Begin and Where Does Niche End
review_content: It was one of those days when I was browsing in my favorite perfume shop, curiously searching for a new olfactory adventure. With a smile, the saleswoman handed me a small sample. “A warm scent,” she said, “Boss, but with a touch of niche.” Her words sounded like a promise that stirred a quiet excitement within me. What could that mean? A scent from Boss that “acts...

Boss Bottled Absolu is, for me, one of the best designer releases for winter in recent years. I also find the design quite nice. It's nothing incredibly daring, but the dark bottle directly conveys the fragrance direction.

The first seconds after application may seem “typically designer,” but as the scent develops a bit, it shows its true face, and this impression stayed with me from the first application.

I am a big fan of leather, but I prefer fruity leather (the master of this category is, of course, Widian London). However, Boss Bottled Absolu goes in a spicier yet still fitting direction. The scent is simply dark and masculine, but I don’t find it "too old." One might think that the notes target an older male audience. I’m in my early 20s and find the scent quite suitable for me!

In general, I find the notes very well balanced: The leather is supported by other notes that give it depth without falling too far in one direction. Despite its spiciness and depth, the scent does not clash - it is different, (especially in the designer sector!) stands out from the mainstream, and still receives compliments from those around.

For me, Boss Bottled Absolu is a great companion for the cold season. Anyone who doesn't have a dark, spicy winter fragrance should definitely give it a try - especially when considering the price/performance ratio. Sillage and longevity are truly in the perfect range, and you can perceive a beautiful development!

... Munich on Sunday, one can admire the figures of the ancient Greeks and Romans. Outside, it is cold and foggy. In front of the sculptures, such as the Munich Kouros and Barberini Faun, which are over 2000 years old, stands a well-groomed, fit middle-aged man. He wears a fitted white turtleneck sweater and white jeans with white sneakers. If he weren't breathing, one might think he is also a sculpture. He is simply mysterious and dark.

Upon applying this fragrance, the first thing that hits the nose is a leathery smokiness with a sweet note. The patchouli adds a dark quality to the scent, while the myrrh contributes resinous, mossy accords. With the davana, fruity spicy and slightly floral notes blend in, rounded off by the woodiness of cedar. This fragrance has a strong masculine twist. The two ladies Annick Ménardo and Suzy Le Helley have created a perfume for men here that, alongside the Elixir, is a true men's scent for Hugo Boss.

The longevity and sillage are very good.

Here we have a fragrance that I see for men aged 21 and up, but it's open-ended above that. It is wearable throughout the year except on warm and hot days. It is an all-rounder that can be worn both in the office, during leisure time, or in the evening when going out, and it will definitely make an impression. I actually see it less on women, but that doesn't mean they shouldn't give it a try.

Anyone who enjoys a smoky, leathery, dark, fruity scent will find a good match here and should give it a go. When it comes to prices, one just has to look for where it can be found at a reasonable price.

Boss Bottled Absolu is, for me, a completely new departure from the previous Bottled DNA and offers a more intense, modernized interpretation of the classic. The combination of fruity apple notes, spicy accords, and a warm, woody base creates an elegant, masculine result. In the top note, the scent is fresh and fruity, with dominant apple notes captured by cinnamon and bergamot. This gives the fragrance a classically warm touch. In the heart note, sharp aromas like cinnamon and nutmeg prevail, adding a slightly sweet depth to the scent. The base remains a legacy of the original Boss Bottled and is a sensual blend of sandalwood, cedar, and vanilla. Performance and longevity are outstanding... for everyday school use, it's almost too much. In my opinion, the fragrance definitely has a niche character and nothing designer-like.

Hugo Boss has some bestsellers in its portfolio (Boss Bottled EAU DE TOILETTE, Hugo EAU DE TOILETTE, The Scent for Him EAU DE TOILETTE), but for a long time, it has been ridiculed as a label with rather mediocre fragrances. However, the men's tailor no longer wants to sit back and is determined to break into the ranks of the most esteemed designers and position itself alongside much more appreciated brands like Dior, Chanel, Tom Ford, or Louis Vuitton. And after recent successes like The Scent Magnetic for Him and "Boss Bottled Elixir | Hugo Boss," which have also been praised in the community for their quality, they are on the right track.

And now "Boss Bottled Absolu | Hugo Boss," to which I wanted to dedicate a review for some time.
Because when I first tried it at the well-known turquoise cosmetics store, I was more than just positively surprised. Alongside my personally favorite Hugo Boss scent, "Boss Bottled Triumph Elixir | Hugo Boss," Boss Bottled Absolu is truly the greatest and best creation of the German fashion label.
Strong, old, very high-quality leather appears together with an almost overwhelming sweetness, along with incense and patchouli as a base. All of this is wonderfully blended together, so that no note completely takes over, but all directions-leathery, smoky, spicy, sweet-form a quartet with equal presence. An absolute date fragrance.
I find the Davana interesting here, which is not often used as a sweet note; usually, vanilla, tonka, or benzoin are chosen. But it has its own charm and fits beautifully between the characters of the other three.

Boss Bottled Absolu has something niche about it, yes, but still, the scent is mass-appealing enough to be successful in a broader market. From this perspective alone, it is excellently crafted.
Additionally, the performance is outstanding. The Absolu projects excellently for 2½ hours, then it pulls back but still radiates for a total of 9 hours. And the fragrance is adorned with one of the most beautiful bottles in the entire line.

Hugo Boss is on the right path. If the future creations of the label maintain the same quality, the designer will surely find itself alongside the aforementioned brands soon.

review_title: Good Flanker, finally a Boss again
review_content:
The Boss Bottled Absolu is, after a long time, a Boss that I like. After the last creations were a bit boring for me, the Absolu convinces me again.

It starts off strong, sweet, yet with a certain extra.
In the opening, the leather hits me with well-crafted incense holding back in the background. Not too much of everything, yet noticeable.

As it develops, myrrh and patchouli are also well executed here.

And in the base notes, you find davana and cedarwood.

A scent perfect for the upcoming or current autumn. Perfect for dreary weather and winter. Too strong and heavy for me in summer.

Longevity and sillage are good.

And the bottle looks very elegant as well. It makes a statement.

When I opened the sample sent to me, I was immediately greeted by a spicy-warm, dry, slightly fruity note that reminded me in a certain way of a well-known tobacco perfume.

As soon as I sprayed it, a resinous, balsamic warmth enveloped me, which I would primarily attribute to myrrh. It is this very balsamic warmth that, together with the prominent incense, gives rise to an oriental, mysterious touch. Starting with a leather note, this is united by patchouli into a deep, earthy, masculine presence, which is completed by cedarwood. And then, more and more, this dry, warm fruitiness emerged, which had greeted me at the very beginning: davana.

I perceive the scent as spicy and subtly oriental. A certain animalic quality can definitely be noted. The sweetness seems pleasantly rounded to me and is more of a nice side effect of the composition rather than being in the foreground. The notes come together to form a complex, deep overall composition that certainly does not need to hide from the niche. Thus, a warm, mysterious, powerful, masculine fragrance emerges, which is particularly suitable for going out, but also for everyday wear in the cold autumn and winter air.

For many years, Boss Bottled EAU DE TOILETTE was a loyal companion for me. In the meantime, I've gotten a bit older and have tried quite a few things - the flankers of the Bottled series offer enough variety to lose track, so I first got a sample of this highly praised candidate:

I can indeed understand the enthusiasm - from my perspective, aside from the classic bottle, it has little in common with the "regular" Bottled. Compared to its brother, it is heavier, warmer, resinous, slightly smoky, sweet-leathery, and a whole different ballgame.

I find the sweetness borderline and can understand that it might be too much for some. I enjoy warm incense and resin scents, so I really appreciate it. Longevity and sillage are really great considering the moderate price. You will definitely be noticed.

Compared to "Red Tobacco | Mancera," which many consider similar, I find it less fruity, less synthetic, but more resinous and leathery.

In my view, it is made for cold days - the strong sweetness fits very well with chilly autumn and winter days.

Well, I have to say: Boss Bottled Absolu is the secret winner in the duel against Layton Exclusif for me. The latter seems to be very popular in the Parfumo community, but to me, Layton Exclusif smells more like an olfactory misstep - or rather, like a trip to the toilet. Seriously, the scent reminds me of a 50-year-old leather couch that has been forgotten in the basement and smells so musty that even the spiders are complaining.
