In contrast, Boss Bottled Absolu is a real surprise! It doesn’t have much in common with the original Boss Bottled, except maybe the name, but that’s a good thing. This fragrance is like a spicy, leathery, smoky adventure for the nose - intense, but not overpowering. It’s a designer perfume that doesn’t feel like 4711, but rather like something special. Thanks to the ingredients, it’s the perfect winter scent for me, ideal for special occasions - or simply for days when you want to feel like the king of the office.

In short: Layton Exclusif? No, thanks. Boss Bottled Absolu? Absolutely yes!

I was tempted to blind order a 50 ml bottle of Boss Bottled Absolu when it was on sale for €52 at Flaconi. Given the extremely positive reviews here, I thought I couldn't go wrong with this scent. Unfortunately, I was very mistaken; this fragrance smells almost 1 to 1 like Pinimenthol Cold Balm from the pharmacy. A herbaceous, bitter-spicy blend, underpinned by a slightly menthol-like freshness.

My toenails are practically curling up, and it almost lifts me off the ground when I smell this "fragrance." I absolutely cannot understand the many positive reviews; for me, it is one of the most unpleasant perfumes I have ever smelled, and everyone in my circle found the scent absolutely repulsive.

You probably need to have a very specific taste to like it; I can only recommend testing it in-store beforehand. On a positive note, the sillage and longevity are both above average.

Unfortunately, I could never warm up to the Boss Bottled DNA…
Every bottle I saw, I held under my nose, and none suited my taste or took a turn that made me decide against an entry. Therefore, I never thought that (spoiler) one would eventually knock my socks off.

When I learned that a new Boss Bottled was being released, I couldn't resist.
And wow, was it worth it!

The opening surprised me right away. It is an intense, spicy start that captivated me immediately. The leather and incense notes are present from the very beginning. Compared to the earlier Boss Bottled fragrances, this one feels much more complex and masculine.

As the top notes settle, a balsamic warmth unfolds, wonderfully supported by the myrrh for me. The spiciness slowly fades away, making room for a warm, almost honey-like sweetness that comes from the Davana. The Davana is also the big player in the pyramid for me! It gives this fragrance a wonderful depth. It is not overpowering but fits perfectly into the overall very masculine composition.

This scent definitely stands out from the crowd. It feels almost like a niche fragrance. It is more intense, more complex, and for me, an absolute surprise.

What can I say, never say never.

"Undercover, the boss mingles with his employees to find out where problems lie and wishes remain unfulfilled."

Do you still remember the show?
Anecdotally, this bottle tells the story of a designer house that has long made its mark on consumers.
Despite a luxury image, expensive campaigns, and well-known faces from film and television, nothing seems to help lift the brand's image. Sales are declining, and the general opinion of the brand is drifting negative.
The efforts of the management, consisting of yes-sayers and overpaid advertising technicians, are also not helping the brand get back on its feet.
The BOSS is on high alert, ready to address the problems that plague his brand. In a simple black outfit and with a discreet hidden gold chain, he immerses himself with utmost concentration into the everyday life and happenings of his company.
In the first weeks, he receives little attention, as efforts are made to involve him in the process as much as possible. He listens and observes. He sets traps here and there for those who think they can behave superficially and inattentively towards him. The resolution, with wide eyes and amazement, awaits each of you, unembellished, professional, and rewarding every good soul who has engaged with him.-

The Boss Bottled Absolu has truly been a surprise for me. For many, the elixir from last year was the first real step, but it didn't really convince me. The Absolu offers a certain overall package that simply appeals to me in the designer sector. It opens with a sweet-spicy cola, similar to the ASAD from Lattafa, and from here it radiates very strongly - the sillage remains quite stable throughout the entire duration of the fragrance, and the longevity is truly impressive. Even after 24 hours, it is still close to the skin and strong enough on clothing to casually continue wearing the scent. The fragrance then develops, alongside the smoky notes, an animalistic touch, which is very harmoniously integrated into the scent. The typical Bottled apple DNA must not be missing, as it makes the fragrance pleasant and versatile - here the comparisons with Layton and its big brother Layton Exclusif are justified, but in my eyes, this fragrance is neither a replacement nor an alternative for the Exclusif. It simply lacks the niche depth and the dark, noble oud component. Nevertheless, I would see it as the best leather fragrance from the house of BOSS. This release takes the Bottled DNA to a new level, even if it is not yet what it might truly aspire to be in the future - a unique selling point, a true BOSS of fragrances. There are simply too many references to other scents.
I have not been able to test the Shaghaf Oud Azraq yet, but it is read as a niche version of this fragrance - this alone would underline my statement here.

And now to the elephant in the room: The price.
€145 for 100 ml RRP.
Anyone who buys at these prices is simply to blame themselves.
Still, I took the plunge during the supposedly good sale, also out of fear of a too-quick reformulation. Because the H/S of the fragrance really made the purchasing decision easy for me.

review_title: Boss Bottled Absolu - a great fragrance
review_content: I have been testing Boss Bottled Absolu for about a year now and I can say: It is a fragrance that I don't want to miss anymore, especially in the cooler season. The first impression right after spraying it is pleasantly fresh and slightly fruity. After just a few minutes, you can feel the warmth setting in. The cinnamon comes through really well, not too sweet, but nicely...

That I would ever write something like this about a Boss Bottled fragrance, I never expected..

Actually, I had already written off Boss Bottled after the countless flankers (all of which have been disappointing for me so far). By chance, I stumbled upon the Absolu here on Parfumo and was intrigued by the strong reviews to give it a try. So off to the nearest drugstore and a spritz on the back of my hand. I was immediately impressed! The scent reminded me of PDM Layton, only with less freshness and more spice. Resinous/smoky, with a slight sweetness. I immediately bought a 100ml bottle and wore it for the first time at the office today. I was approached multiple times throughout the day, asking what fragrance I was wearing. Even my wife could still detect it in the evening, 10 hours after application, wow! Longevity and sillage are therefore extremely good, and that from a Boss Bottled. I never expected that…

Long story short: great scent with outstanding performance. I would already call this Beastmode quality. A clear recommendation to buy!

review_title: Don't Get Too Caught Up in the Hype…
review_content:
I was led to a blind buy by various reviews and opinions and I am a bit disappointed. I find the scent itself very good and I like it, so it was definitely not a bad purchase.
However, I cannot share the assessment as Fragrance of the Year. The niche has quite a bit more to offer.

In the top notes, there is a lot of leather that quickly fades, making way for wood and incense. Simple but nice.

Who would have thought that after the Elixir by HBB, which is quite successful, there would be another enhancement? I took my time with this statement to thoroughly test this fragrance, so I wouldn't judge too hastily and say it wasn't that great before I let myself be swayed into this review. It's astonishing that this flanker evokes such different memories in me; sometimes I think I smell a Red Tobacco, then again a bit of associations from the Bottled Elixir. I can't pin it down and say: It definitely smells like this or that… no, it's a bit of everything, and yet there's something unique about it. What makes this fragrance special for me is the Davana, the leather, and the incense in combination, which I can smell well and gives it a nice twist. I also noticed that fragrances created in collaboration with at least two or more perfumers in the industry usually receive a good reception or become a sales hit. Like in this case with Annick Ménardo and Suzy Le Helley (who admittedly doesn't have as long a list of creations as the former) but still: Just like with the HBB Elixir before, they created something beautiful together. I see this phenomenon with many other hits that have come out over the years, like the legendary AdG EDT (in which Annick Ménardo also contributed to this hit), "La Nuit de L'Homme" EDT, or "Tuscan Leather," to name just a few, where there was a collaboration of different perfumers. There are several other well-known fragrances that are currently not coming to mind as I write this review, but they should be quite famous, so pay attention to that. Usually, a beautiful fragrance hit comes out of it that later has or finds many fans. I mean, I heard that in the past, "parfum creators/perfumers" positively influenced or inspired each other, which is certainly possible; I don't know if that's true or complete nonsense, whatever. Also, the newer fragrances, including the Gucci Guilty Elixir, which is admittedly quite new like HBB Elixir and the "Absolu" in this case, have to establish themselves first to become a hit. But these are the fragrances that are mostly positively accepted by the majority and are well-made perfumes, just like those mentioned. It's not the case with all perfumes that have actually become well-known sales hits over the years (like with Maestro François Demachy, who created many heavyweights starting from the Dior Homme range (Parfum, Intense, etc.) to the Sauvage range, which he also created alone as far as I know. And despite that, they became big hits. That doesn't mean anything. But one thing must be remembered for the future: At least I will remember this for myself, when a fragrance comes out that has been created by more than one person or was developed in collaboration: Then there is a VERY high probability that it will be good or at least a potential success or bestseller.

If Boss Bottled were a teenager, it would have become a man with the release of the Absolu. And Boss has done a lot right in its various product lines over the past years. Starting with the marketing, where they brought in a lot of prominent support (Chris Hemsworth, Emma Roberts, Jacob Elordi, for example) to truly high-quality fragrances that, especially in the Bottled product line, have now moved far beyond the old Bottled clichés.

During the first scent test, I was surprised that the Absolu and the new The Scent Elixir resemble each other a bit. However, this is only superficial. The Absolu feels even more masculine, has a lower sillage, and becomes significantly woodier and fresher over time due to the patchouli notes, while the Scent Elixir is noticeably warmer, more intense, and sweeter. Both fragrances are completely independent, but they show me that the Bottled line is taking a much more elegant approach.

I recently received a sample of the Absolu and subsequently bought a small bottle on sale, which will last me a long time since I always spray it discreetly. But the Boss Bottled Absolu will most likely become a preferred companion for my evening outings. A thoroughly successful release.

The fragrance opens with a distinctive leather note, enveloped in incense. Davana and cedarwood round off the composition with a warm, woody, slightly sweet base. Despite the lack of official mention, a juicy apple note flashes through, giving the fragrance a subtle freshness. Overall, it is very dark, oriental, and masculine.

I smelled Hugo Boss Bottled the new Absolu… last year in September and was immediately blown away, the scent has something niche about it, it develops permanently on my skin, it really smells intense. The sillage is really 10/10 for me, my friends could smell it from what felt like 3-4m away. The price is good, but I think it will get even better in the next few months.

From my perspective, BB Elixir has been enhanced with something (good), making it an upgrade. I tested it on a strip and on my skin. It was striking how prominently a honey scent emerged for me after the initial sweetness faded a bit - like sticking my nose into a jar of honey. Then, after maybe an hour, the BB Elixir clearly revealed itself alongside honey, leather, and sweet...

review_title: Not a "normal" designer fragrance - a statement from Boss
review_content: This scent clearly stands out from the crowd. Not an ordinary designer fragrance, but a surprisingly complex, profound composition - and yes, indeed from Hugo Boss! At the first sniff, I was immediately captivated: smoky, spicy, warm - simply powerful. Frankincense, sweet leather, cedarwood - these are exactly the notes that define the profile. The fragrance envelops the...

review_title: This Apple Falls Quite Far from the Tree
review_content:
My experiences with BOSS Bottled ended long before the flankers really took off. Sorry to all who like the EDT, but even as a teenager, the original Bottled was the most boring scent ever for me.

So I didn't really pay any attention to the Bottled line for a very long time. Now and then, I came across a sample of the EDP&Co. Those didn't really grab me either. Accordingly, I was quite surprised at how beautiful the Absolu turned out to be.

The scent starts with a leathery fruitiness. It smells like a sweet apple in a leather bag. The patchouli tingles a bit in the nose and gives the fragrance a certain masculinity.
When the spiciness fades, a kind of candied fruits remains with soft resins. The davana wraps the dry down in a sweet-balsamic finish.

Beautiful for the cooler days. The longevity is definitely above average. On clothing, you can still smell the fragrance easily the next day.

So I love it and I'm excited about the development of the Bottled line. Although the apple could be recognized again, the Absolu has long left boredom behind. It is a clear recommendation.

Best regards, Andi

review_title: Leather Gasoline (or is it just me smelling the gasoline from Fahrenheit?)
review_content: Hello to all readers, my second longer engagement, after being drawn into the world of perfume quite late, is about a scent that immediately reminded me of my first real fragrance from my youth: Fahrenheit EAU DE TOILETTE! Two days ago, I was strolling with my daughter in search of shoes through various stores, only to randomly end up in a D. where I wanted to...

I happened to find this one discounted along with the others in the Woody Collection. Strange to see them already being discounted/discontinued? since I think they just came out, but am very glad to have this in my collection! Some say similar to Santal 33, I will have to do a side-by-side test, but this frag is good enough to stand on it's own

review_title: Undertones of the Leathery and Smoky Notes
review_content:
I popped into the ZARA shop before dinner one late evening, I saw the newbies from Swedish Collection, and I spritzed some of the Tiveden on to test it, and for the rest of the night, I could not stop sniffing my wrist. It was masculine, and it was tad feminine, it was smoky, it was woody, it was leathery, it was shape-shifting in my nostrils, it was elegant but edgy, it was sophisticated but down-to-earth. In summary, it was love, pure love.
Now that I've smelled the smoky-powdery-leathery vibes of ZARA Tiveden, I'm addicted. I'm taking solace that, because no one in my office wears it yet, I'm still kind of a special snowflake.

For one thing, despite the Swedish name, I find this to be a predominantly leather-focused scent, with salty, green cucumbers or better pickles quality that is almost aquatic. It opens with a powerful blast of green cardamom, with its pungent yet elusive flavor, resinous and dark with hints of eucalyptus, sea salt, leather, and that aqueous herbal element. Perhaps, there is a tad of tarragon or drill in the headnotes, not listed on the official site.

What makes a fragrance intriguing is when it evokes a specific time, a certain place, or a particular material while remaining elusively vague. ZARA Tiveden is intensely masculine: full of raw, oily leather and balsam. It makes me think of a lifestyle concept store – one of those deep-toned, white empty studio spaces where they place a tangle of dried white driftwood in one corner and a long leather couch in the other. Close your eyes, breathe, and let your mind go in there.

Much later on, in the far dry down, there is the aroma of the raw and brusquely woods, and it is only then I see the reference to sandalwood. But, in general, this is dry and woody-leathery, not lactonic or sweet. The more I sniff it, the more I get the unusual smell of genuine leather exuding from a brand new handmade coat, belt, or pair of shoes.
It reminds me of books, too. In particular in the raw, harsh chemical breeze of salt, which ultimately comes off as a combination of freshly-tanned leather and newly-printed paper.

Oh man, no question about it. With superior performance to boot, this is another winning hand from the house of ZARA. Well done! Be sure to give it a chance before damning it after the first sniff – you might eventually enjoy it!

Ultimately, the smell lies on the masculine side and can be worn well in the fall. It's a warm, woodlike smell that I found surprisingly identical to the way the forest smells after it rains. It captures the scent of damp earth, ferns, creek water, cedar, and wet leather. Woodsy like the aroma of the freshly-cut wood you get in a sawmill or lumber mill, where logs are cut into lumber... Ever been to a lumber yard? It's that scent. Beautiful woods just cut. It's terrific and entirely wearable.

At this point, it's weird if someone doesn't smell like Tiveden by ZARA!!!

Update: longevity and sillage are enormous. I've been wearing it since 8.00 am, and after almost 7 hours, it is still alive and kicking, and I do love it!

-Elysium

As a woman, I am writing the first comment on this men's fragrance... so far, there have only been statements.

Apparently, this new perfume from Zara is rather controversial.

To me, it primarily comes across as fresh, especially at the beginning, even though hardly anyone seems to feel the same way. This freshness comes from the cardamom. Anyone who has ever opened a bag of the green pods (e.g., from the Asian market) knows this incomparable, almost camphor-like aroma.
Furthermore, I would have suspected iris due to a dry-powdery, slightly "carrot-like" note, even though it is not mentioned.
I perceive the leather note as rather subdued, although clearly detectable - here as light leather, not aged, old, spicy leather.
“Tiveden” strikes me as bright-woody, wintry, powdery-clean, but not creamy and not sweet in the slightest. It makes me think of sunshine and powdered snow - a winter walk (in "picture-book winter weather") or a ski slope...

Unfortunately, “Tiveden” lasts very poorly on my skin. After the lovely cardamom opening, I can soon only sense a subtle hint on my skin.

review_title: Extremely odd and I love it
review_content: I know this is marketed and discussed as a floral gourmand, but boy is this one strange for me (and in the best way, as I love strange frags). While I get an initial lilac burst in the beginning, I wouldn't describe this one as overly floral like one might expect a lilac-forward frag to be. It's floral powderiness remains present throughout, but I'm not getting the heady spring blooms that I'm seeing others describe. And I also don't get a sticky sweet gourmand from this either. The first few minutes to me read almost like a hint of lilac with a hint of something dessert like, but mostly whatever this combo is, reads to me more like something akin to dusty burnt wires. Annnd...I'm kinda digging it. I can't even explain why, but I keep coming back to this frag and its strangeness. 5-10 min in, the marzipan does come out and the fragrance turns a bit sweeter, but I definitely do not get a rich sweet gourmand or a punchy floral from this frag. There's a lot of nuance here. I haven't smelled anything like it and I'm continuously intrigued by the complexity of this one and the journey it takes me on.

I'm confused by this one. This smells like a tobacco bomb and yet, there's no tobacco note. I happen to like tobacco notes, but I can only imagine what a diehard gourmand lover would think when they spray this after seeing notes of marzipan, tonka, whipped cream, rhubarb...

It's giving cinnamon tobacco sweetness. Very strange. I like it, but was hoping for something cool with the lilac note and didn't really get it.

review_title: Marzipan cookie w/ a whisper of lilac
review_content:
I have to preface this by saying I do not prefer gourmands. I do, however, love lilac, so I really wanted to try this one.

Unfortunately, the lilac did not come through at the start. The rhubarb was very acidic on my skin, verging on sour. That acidity sat on top of the cookie accord for a long time. And when I say cookie, I mean an almond cookie with almond frosting and almonds on top. It was sweet, sweet marzipan, and that sweetness was cloying to me, personally.

The dry down became much more pleasant. The vanilla began to shine with the patchouli, and I finally felt like I could smell some of that lilac coming through.

In the end, it became a very familiar scent. Like a lotion or candle from long ago that you will never remember the name of. I do think it is a vanilla almond scent before it is a lilac scent, and for that reason, it wasn't a win for me. But it's definitely a win for someone out there!

This comes dangerously close to diaper territory, but somehow manages to pull off powdery, creamy, and floral together without going full-on poopoo. It feels so clean, like I just got out of the shower, but wrapped in a big fluffy robe and also it's kinda hot outside so the robe is making me a little sweaty.
.
The mimosa and rhubarb give it a light twang to elevate the powdery aspects. Cream, vanilla, and tonka add an addictive gourmand base without making things too sweet. I think the lack of sweetness is part of the reason it's not entirely poopy pants. The notes in this one twine together so well, which gives such an interesting scent experience. Sometimes I'll get lilac as the star, sometimes tonka, sometimes rhubarb, even the cinnamon pops out every once in a while!
.
Definitely sample-worthy if you're a gourmand lover who wants something interesting for spring time, or if you, like me, are becoming more adventurous when it comes to note combinations.

This feels like spring is here. Lilacs are blooming, the sky is clear and the day is warm while you sit on the grass amongst the flowers eating a creme brulee. This is a creative gourmand that is combines it's creaminess with green and floral notes. Almost as if your dessert is decorated with edible flowers in that they add a little something extra to the star of the show. This fragrance is really good but there was something a little off in the depths of this fragrance, a weird starch-ness to the fragrance. I hate to say it, but that starch I was picking up reminded me of opening a box of instant mash potatoes. It wasn't strong but it was noticable enough to distract me from fully enjoying this fragrance. The starch faded after a few hours but it lasted long enough that I cannot fall in love with this fragrance.

This fragrance has some floral lift for the first hour or two but mainly its a sweet skin scent. It is long lasting, over 8 hours on my skin even after I washed the area. There are two sizes and prices available starting at 9ml for $58 and 30ml for $145. Fairly pricey but if you can't detect that starchy-ness like I can, then this is definitely a unique and creative enough scent that it would be worth the price.

She lay completely still. It was almost dark; only a single oil lamp cast its feeble glow through the room. She was cold, even though it was a very warm evening. The women had just left, and a half-dozen mutilated servants had carried the large tub away. In the air and on her skin lingered a slightly soapy scent of roses and saffron, which could have been delightful. Her body had been thoroughly washed, shaved, anointed, and perfumed. What a ridiculousness that she was cleaned just to be soiled again right after.

For he would come to her again today: she had only been in the palace for a few days. As long as his ardor lasted, he came every evening to his latest wife, it was said. Until he wanted the next one and discarded the previous one among the others.

Most families that received the message - rather the command - from the Sultan to give him their daughter in marriage bowed down, perhaps feeling it was an honor. But not all; and her kin, led by her mother, had not complied. A brave, strong woman who had known what awaited her daughter and had wanted to spare her such a fate. Especially since a wedding with a lover was imminent. It had done no good, but a family and this time even a fiancé had been accused of a despicable offense, and for their resistance had to pay with their lives.

It was hard to believe that as a little girl she had envied the women of the Sultan. For the lavish, days-long wedding celebrations, for example. Or when a palanquin glided through the streets as if it had floated out of a fairy tale, surrounded by an incomprehensible fragrance of rose petals and gentle spices. She had imagined being cared for by dozens of willing hands. There had been no golden cage or groping fingers in her childish thoughts.

He would have bathed as well, would be perfumed with the scent of fiery spices, which nevertheless could not conceal his true filth. He never wasted much time. He would throw off his garment, pull down her blanket, and roughly knead her breasts for a moment. Then he would push his powerful belly against her and shove her legs aside. If they did not obey immediately, clumsy hands would help with brute force, and he would take possession of her. Well, he would believe he was taking possession of her, as only such a man might think. But he would never possess her; her innermost self remained hers.

After each time, she had to think of her lover with tears of pain and sorrow in her eyes and of the only secret time when he had been able to come to her. As clueless as they had been, as awkward the hands of young people must have been, they had touched each other so tenderly and sensitively, so lovingly, later passionately and impetuously. She had willingly let him in - what could happen, just a few days before the wedding? It had been unexpected, a little frightening. And wonderful. Quickly, their kisses had to stifle the sounds of both.

She shuddered and pulled the thin blanket tighter around herself at the thought of what nightmare it had now become. And she could count herself lucky that the Sultan had not noticed that he was by no means the first. The days and nights since the pompous wedding had passed like behind a veil of dull horror. But the day before yesterday morning, she had woken up with a completely clear mind and had known what to do.

After a short time above her, he would start grunting like one of the wild boars from the forests. The smell of his sweat would invade her nose. And although it would be the mild, fresh scent of an outwardly clean body, she would feel covered in animalistic stench when the little streams sprang from his sides and his heated belly and laid a slippery film over her body. Then, all of a sudden, it would be over. Almost.

She had thought everything through carefully. With two fingers of her right hand, she would feel for the right ribs beneath the leathery bulges on his back. Yesterday she had tried it; with some pressure, it worked. He would take her firm grip for the excitement that the other women had advised her to feign, and would grin foolishly and self-satisfied. He truly believed he was providing pleasure! As soon as he lay exhausted on her, she could take the stolen knife from the kitchen - it was already under the pillow - and stab it through his heart from behind her fingers. And when she had rolled him off her, it would graciously take her own life as well.

The door opened, and a beam of light fell into the room. A moment later, a shapeless silhouette darkened the light.

Angelliese, oh Angelliese, what have you done? You lavish me with beautiful samples from Rasasi and El Nabil, and I fear I won't be able to sleep peacefully without one or the other from the collection. However, the Sultan won't keep me awake anymore, as it will be arriving at my place tomorrow. A quick decision that I surely won't regret after wearing it enthusiastically three times.

What kind of magic water is this that captivates me so? Musc Sultan starts with a surprise that you wouldn't necessarily expect given the fragrance notes listed above: a wonderfully fresh, juicy lemon opening that doesn't come across as ethereal-light like a cologne, but somehow thicker, more substantial... I don't know how to express it. This so-called "meaty" lemon gradually becomes sweeter, accompanied by a lovely, delicate rose that forms a very harmonious connection with the lemon. This is soon complemented by spicy-sweet saffron, which increasingly takes the lead in the fragrance journey. A very successful, balanced composition for my nose.

Only after about an hour does the namesake musk begin to emerge more prominently, initially in a well-balanced interplay with the spicy saffron, then infused with more woody notes. For a while, the musk even takes on a slightly animalistic direction until it finally develops into the musk that I love so much: warm, soft, trustworthy, sensual.

Who would have thought? A truly high-quality smelling perfume without a hint of cheap synthetic notes, an exciting, versatile fragrance development, very good longevity, strong sillage up to the rather skin-close musky finale... and all of this for under €20 for 50 ml - what more could one want?

Sensual, extraordinary, dense, elegant, refined, in one word CARON.

This little treasure has unfortunately been languishing in my cabinet until now, and today was such a strange, actually funny, dark, dull afternoon/evening that I decided to revisit my fine samples that I wasn't ready to test yet.

Now I have done it and am very surprised, at the same time relieved but also ashamed that I waited so long that I no longer know who gave me this wonderful fragrance. I also don't know if it is the pure perfume, but I assume it is, as it has been hovering around me for so long, smelling, smelling, smelling, simply brilliantly beautiful.

It is floral, balsamic, yellow-powdery, spicy, resinous, but it is also the true French elegance, everything you can imagine is here, and I am unable to pick out anything specific. I only know one thing, it is dreamy, a jewel of the art of fragrance, and it has completely captivated me.

Dear Iris, I strongly suspect that it comes from your treasure chamber, which you always so kindly open for us and in your lovely way also let others partake in, so I thank you from the bottom of my heart for that and already regret it when the AF will someday (I fear in not too distant a future) be emptied.

A lot of lemon and clove oil, is my impression. These materials are also mentioned by the label, along with rosemary. I think I can also smell orange oil. So quite culinary, which is why it doesn’t remind me of cleaning products, and I don’t perceive any bitter orange oils, making it not similar enough to 4711 to seem outdated. The combination of citrus oils with kitchen herbs seems to never have gone out of style. The top note of the Saint Helena Cologne is zesty, cheerful, and delicious. However, the essential oils are so volatile that the scent - on skin as well as on clothing - can only be perceived from close proximity after just a few minutes, and after an hour, hardly even that. This heart/base phase smells not only sour and spicy but also oily, perhaps due to the rosemary.

Regarding the historical background, the information on napoleon-cologne.fr is a bit confusing for me; I have laid out the following sequence: Napoleon arrived in his exile on Saint Helena in 1815 and used a Cologne imported from Europe, though it is unknown which one. In 1819, there was a supply gap - unclear why - and Napoleon's entourage, specifically his chamberlain and librarian Louis-Étienne Saint-Denis (known as Mamelouk Ali), created a Cologne on Saint Helena that was supposed to resemble the one imported until then. In the English text (usa.napoleon-cologne.com), it sounds as if local plants were used:

“Mameluke Ali pieced together the Eau de Cologne in a traditional way according to the local resources available on the island. Nearby, he mainly had access to citrus trees from which he extracted and collected the essences contained in the fruit peel, using compression with a natural sponge. He also harvested rosemary and cloves, which he distilled to extract their essence. These oils and some others were then mixed with wine spirit in good proportions.”

For practical reasons, I suspect that imported supplies of fruits and spices were used - the French text leaves this possibility open, as it speaks of “des citrus” instead of “citrus trees” and uses the more general “récolter” instead of “harvest.” It would be interesting to know, at least for me, which oils besides the explicitly mentioned ones were used. In any case, probably no special perfume ingredients like bergamot oil. The improvised distillation of any flower oils also seems unlikely to me. More conceivable are other herbs, perhaps in small quantities and therefore not easily identifiable by scent, which could also explain the Farnesol in the allergen list. The citrus fruits were probably simply lemons and oranges.

Napoleon died in 1821, so the Saint Helena Cologne was in use for a maximum of two years. The text mentions a temporary shortage (“disette momentanée,” “disette qui régnait à certains moments”) - so it is conceivable that even only a single batch was produced. The recipe eventually reached Jean Kerléo, co-founder of the Osmothèque in Versailles, from the estate of Saint-Denis, no earlier than 1991. What exact contribution he made is unclear to me. He must have interpreted the information on materials and quantities, and perhaps he also thought about the growing areas and extraction methods of that time. Soon after, marketing began as an olfactory reminiscence of Napoleon, possibly already in the square bottle that is currently shown in the Parfumo photo. “Les parfums historiques” assures, citing the Osmothèque, that the formula corresponds to the original and is “100% natural”; however, no information is provided regarding geographical origin and processing.

The cylindrical bottle advertised on napoleon-cologne.fr has apparently been available since 2020. The formula must have remained the same, but the price per milliliter has increased. The old bottle is still available in some French online shops, which is how I got my current 100-ml bottle in 2021 (for €54 with free shipping). A 25-ml size seems to have recently been added.

These are not prices at which one can spray oneself all over every hour with a clear conscience to survive hot weekends. For this purpose, one would also need to find more refreshing scents, perhaps more with bergamot or bitter orange and fresher spices. Well, spraying once to put oneself in the mindset of the exiled emperor is certainly justifiable. Otherwise, for me, it is a scent that one enjoys a little, briefly, from time to time. However, citrus oils are said not to last too long even in the -opened- bottle. As I understand it, these oils in modern perfumes are usually concentrated and thus more durable; in comparison, this historical Cologne could therefore age particularly quickly. On the skin, however, even modern fixatives seem not to make the most beautiful citrus aromas significantly longer-lasting. Since the suspected ingredients are all easily available as pure essential oils, a diffuser could be a cost-effective alternative with a longer duration of effect; I have no experience with that.

Personal background (for particularly leisurely readers): My parents brought back a bottle as a souvenir from France, probably in the late 90s, possibly with thoughts of our house cat Napoleon. In any case, the still-packaged bottle was displayed on a shelf near the cat litter for years before I had the idea to try the scent. At that time, I only knew various soapy men's fragrances, which I found unpleasant, but whose social function I understood. The Saint Helena Cologne, without a clear reference to gender, age, or social status and already through its very short-term external effect decidedly non-functional, offered me a completely different perspective. (To engage further with perfumes at that time, the Cologne perhaps seemed too much of an exception, and I lacked an idea of how such a hobby could be affordable.)

This is a really beauty! It's all about white flowers, sandalwood and vanilla, beautifully mixt. A perfect fragrance for spring and summer, but it can be worn all year round! It's sweet, but not too sweet, it has a fresh hint, it's also woody, it's sensual, it's a very elegant but modern fragrance - a beauty that you should not miss! The bottle - just astonishing beautiful! And yes, it's very similar to Givenchy L'Interdit.

For the love of god here I go again about the macerating/maturing thing! It’s not even a slight different it’s HUGE! Every single Arab perfume I’ve ever bought (kayali too) is not worth touching for at least 2 months. This one has been left for 6 months probably and I’d genuinely given up. Moved my perfumes into a new cupboard today and gave it a sniff. Where did the sweet creaminess come from. This was a sharp powder bomb last time I smelt it. I’m thrilled and I’ll be wearing it out for a meal tonight. It’s gorgeous. Just don’t throw your scents out for a long time

the opening is fruity (but not juicy) and not too sweet, with plenty of white floral - although the flowers are blitz-blended here, to the point where it’s impossible to pick up much more than the jasmine.
as the concoction settles, the tuberose (which is reminiscent of a poorly executed, synthetic peony note) resurfaces from under the layers of jasmine and it does start being screechy - for some reason it’s giving me vintage ysl and a headache.

it was much better on the blotter than on the skin but now i'm too traumatized to spray it again... (yeah i had to change clothes and scrub my wrist twice to get rid of the smell)

edit: i gave it 9 months. 9 months to cook and macerate and somehow develop. it's nothing more than screechy, cloying, overly sweet, god forsaken tuberose. my wrist hurts from how hard i just scrubbed it off.

As has often been read, this fragrance is very similar to L'Interdit (2018) EAU DE PARFUM. But still with subtle differences. Givenchy comes across as more delicate and refined.

This one is louder. It screams "Here I am! An elegant, well-dressed lady. I know how to behave. I wear expensive, noble clothing. My designer handbag in hand. But still, I love chewing gum, that delicious pink Hubba Bubba. Sometimes making a bubble with it. Even if that’s not quite lady-like."

I really enjoy wearing it. However, it has to fit. In everyday life, it could quickly become too much for me. The bottle is an oriental dream, like most of Lattafa's creations.

Floral-sweet jasmine scent. The tuberose comes through beautifully. Suitable for everyday use/evening, spring/summer/autumn/winter - young & old! Classy. Develops wonderfully on the skin. But you really need to use about 3-4 sprays. Then the longevity and sillage are also top-notch. Just like L'Interdit (2018) EAU DE PARFUM

I gifted the fragrance to my wife because I was so curious about it. I've read several times that the scent is supposed to be good. And I must say it did not disappoint either my wife or me. The price-performance ratio is incredible. You basically get the L'Interdit (2018) EAU DE PARFUM for around 20€.

There are some fragrances from Lattafa that are beautiful. But just as many that I don't like. You have to test them out.

review_title: Fakhar Lattafa Women by Lattafa - A Luxurious Masterpiece
review_content: The fragrance is like a gentle breeze rising from the most hidden, damp corners of a forest and suddenly transitioning into a sea of white flowers. The tuberose and sambac jasmine dance in the air, while the earthiness of the forest floor remains hidden beneath, gentle yet always present. The floral notes dominate; they are strong yet delicate, like a wave of soft silk laying...

So this is my first review, and it's for a Lattafa fragrance. At first, I thought the now so hyped scents from the Orient would smell very typical: heavy, rosy, sticky-sweet, overly rosy-patchouli, etc.

Until I smelled Fakhar rose-gold!

I must say that I can't recognize and dissect the individual elements of a fragrance as well as most people here; I can only say whether I like it or not and possibly whether it is heavy, sweet, floral, fresh, woody, or oriental

This one surprised me right from the first sniff: to my perception, fresh and floral at the same time, not my favorite direction but still pleasant and beautiful. After 20-30 minutes, the floral freshness gradually fades into the background, and a mature, feminine, deep scent follows: vanilla-sandalwood, just how I like it. It stays that way, and I love it. However, I must say that it doesn't last that long on the skin, but on the sweater, it lasts longer.

To what extent it resembles L'interdit, I don't want to evaluate, as I don't own it. But I could imagine that it smells similarly mature, feminine, and elegant :)

review_title: First fruity, sparkling, then powdery, seductive
review_content:
Yesterday I tested "Fakhar Lattafa Women | Lattafa / لطافة" by Lattafa... and I have to say: it really surprised me positively! The opening is totally pleasant - floral, fruity, fresh - I immediately get notes of lychee, peony, and white peach. The peach (aldehydes) makes the scent sweet yet clean. I can't confirm the listed fragrance notes here. The floral aspect of the scent comes a bit later. At this point, it reminds me a little of Chance Eau Tendre EAU DE TOILETTE or a light Delina EAU DE PARFUM.
Really sparkling and feminine!
After a while, it develops into something more powdery, more intense… the rose and jasmine, orange blossom, and tuberose become more prominent, accompanied by a fine sweetness, but not heavy or overloaded.
In the drydown, it becomes softer, warmer, and sweeter: vanilla, musk, and sandalwood come into play, giving the scent a seductive, opulent note.

Fakhar Women actually reminds me of L’Interdit by Givenchy, but for me personally, Fakhar is somehow more wearable. L’Interdit has too much tuberose for me; I find Fakhar more pleasant because it is also feminine and sensual but not quite as dense and "in your face".

Overall: a beautiful, versatile scent that can be easily worn in everyday life, but also has something to offer for the evening. Price-performance is really top-notch like with almost all Lattafas!
For me, it won't be joining my collection, as I probably wouldn't wear it often.

A really great, powdery, floral light scent. Unfortunately, it doesn't last very long on me. The price-performance ratio is very good though.
The bottle is simply beautiful and very sturdy.

No headaches and overwhelming patchouli. Tuberose is also not too dominant in the foreground.
Clearly a light, powdery, feminine, everyday-appropriate jasmine.

What you can also do wonderfully with the perfume is layer it.

Perfectly suitable for all occasions.

For me, this is a good everyday fragrance; I like to wear it to work. I only use 1-2 sprays, so it's not too loud. I really like the heart notes of jasmine and tuberose. I find the bottle very beautiful, and it is also suitable as a gift (if you know the preferences). I think the longevity is good as well.

Let's continue with another women's fragrance. Lattafa really has some great options in their range and always offers truly wonderful alternatives to some bestsellers from niche and mainstream. This Fakhar line is also quite popular. While the male counterpart leans towards YSL Y, this is clearly an alternative to Givenchy's L'Interdit (2018) EAU DE PARFUM. This line from Givenchy is already one of my favorites when it comes to women's designer lines. I love these playful floral notes of orange blossom and tuberose with a slight bubblegum touch. There is also a Fakhar Extrait, which has nothing to do with the previous Fakhar fragrances and stands on its own. With this white bottle featuring a bronze-colored cap and cover, you get this L'Interdit, which is priced at around €80 for 80ml. Here, you pay the usual Lattafa prices of €20 for 100ml. For a small budget, it's definitely worth buying.

Even though this bottle is white, this fragrance is certainly not a white scent. The bottle is visually appealing and quite typical for this brand. I love these beautiful bronze tones in a glossy finish. In some shops and websites, it is listed as Fakhar Rose, which, however, does not appear on the bottle.
The pyramid seems to be incomplete here. Some components are missing, such as the fruity notes that provide great fruity-floral vibes, especially in the opening. Present in this Fakhar is a wonderful fruit mix and also a great pomegranate note. At the heart of the fragrance is, of course, this well-known floral heart note with tuberose, orange blossom, and jasmine. This mix is 100% feminine and somehow slightly playful. This is also due to the tuberose note, which has such light bubblegum vibes as is often the case with this note. It smells similar to L'Interdit and does not come off as cheap. The fruity notes also match well with this floral heart note. The floral mix feels vibrant and has that certain something that I also love about the original Givenchy. This has been well executed here and provides wonderful sensual-feminine notes. The base consists of sensual-sweet notes with vanilla, musk, amber/ambroxan, and also gentle sandalwood. The white musk gives a creamy impression. Overall, a well-rounded "dupe" that convinces me, even though I am usually "Team Original". The original is a bit rounder, but for about €20, it's an easy blind buy and a great option for everyday use. However, the DNA is rather not for daily wear due to the strong bubblegum tuberose.
Performance is also strong like that of Givenchy. The sillage is really strong and impressive. It is perceived by many and lasts around 10 hours, with the last hours becoming a bit closer to the skin and softer.

Overall, a clear recommendation for women with a small budget. It smells sexy and slightly playful. I can recommend it, especially as an evening and casual fragrance.

I am a bit confused and believe that the fragrance pyramid here is incorrect. On the Lattafa website, it lists "Lattafa Perfume Fakhar Femme" as follows:

Top notes: Bergamot, Lily, Pomegranate;
Heart notes: Rose, Jasmine, Honeysuckle, Tuberose, Peony, Gardenia;
Base note: Vanilla, Sandalwood, Ambroxan, white musk

Or am I mistaken and this is a completely different scent? (feel free to let me know)

When I tried it, at first it had a bit of a gum-like quality and over time became so indefinably sweet (which, in my opinion/experience, would suggest vanilla in the base note), I only perceive the floral notes very subtly. It is not overly intense and not "sticky" sweet, but it only lasts moderately well on my skin even with several sprays.
As I perceive it (with an untrained nose, however), the fragrance pyramid here on Parfumo does not match.

...or maybe I'm just too young to like it.

Because this is by no means a bad perfume: The flowers are wonderfully present, especially the jasmine blossom, and envelop one in a creamy white scent. Objectively, I can only praise it, and yet I do not like it.

Perhaps it’s because my grandmother's powder had a similar note.
Perhaps it’s because I simply expected something fresher.
Perhaps it’s because I am a man and not so well-versed in the world of women's perfumes ;)

Either way, at this price, you can definitely give it a try if you like floral-creamy-powdery scents!

Personally, I am a huge fan of extraordinary fragrances with very good longevity and sillage. I miss that a little here.

All in all, "Fakhar Lattafa Women | Lattafa / لطافة" is a very nice scent. Jasmine and tuberose come through well, so it really smells pleasant. As an everyday fragrance for the office, the perfume is great, as it is not too loud and not too noticeable. I find the longevity and sillage to be rather mediocre, so it's not a banger like some others from the Lattafa brand. However, for the affordable price, you can't go wrong with this scent.
The sample is enough for me - I probably won't be getting a bottle.

This fragrance evokes memories of my childhood 30 years ago. My mother had a cream with a balsamic scent in a ceramic container - I have been searching for a scent just like this for a long time.
The fragrance is very powdery and floral and, in my opinion, lasts surprisingly long. Even the next day, I can still perceive it in my clothing. I really like this scent, but I couldn't wear it every day as it is very prominent.

I don't know the original scent :)
I bought Fakhar Lattafa Women EAU DE PARFUM on vacation, as the beautiful one quickly wrapped me around her finger. It's a really great cheapie that's worth the little money!

To me, the scent smells like vacation. Freshly washed, lotioned flowers.
Clean, well-groomed, and warm but without being overwhelming. I could wear it easily at 30 degrees and above without getting a headache. Strangely enough, I was approached about the scent several times. The niche fragrances are usually not worth mentioning, but this one brought me endless compliments :D.

My nose can't untangle anything here, so no detailed review. I can't detect the aforementioned orange blossom, vetiver, or anything like that. However, the overall scent profile is really good and definitely worth a sniff!

Every person has experienced certain things in their life that they do not want to be reminded of. Whether it is out of guilt, bad memories or experiences, it doesn't matter, but people prefer to keep quiet about it. Some moments do not tolerate the daylight and take place in the middle of the night, dark, sinister and above all unimaginable and unpredictable. What if this
secret comes out? Secrecy surrounding a fact is not acceptable to many. It leads to speculation and usually ends in denial. This also happened ages ago and not much has changed since then...Incubus became famous for this.

Is the fragrance Incubus really as brutal , violent and sinister as history would want us to believe ? Of course not.

If you're immediately tempted by a gift of chocolate, fresh fruit and a bunch of tuberose the first time you meet, you know it could become serious. What else can you expect from this seduction ritual? Try to focus on the other person, not on yourself because the first moments determine whether it will become the truth or whether you will be left alone again.
His leather jacket is old, probably worn at every date. But his leather pants suits his body perfectly, as it was made hand tailored. All stitching is done with so much precision that it's almost too perfect...too perfect for the man who wears it ? What is he hiding and why? It is sometimes said that there is a beast in every person, so I am warned, but not afraid.
Why should I, I've been through worse haven't I? I let myself be overwhelmed at that moment, Incubus seduces me with a ritual that can be experienced as painful slowly. He comes closer, too close, you smell his breath. He smoked just before entering the room, the smell still lingers around him but you will be surprised because it smells like something creamy, sweet balsamic and even a bit powdery feminine which makes him irresistibly attractive. Your space becomes his space, in between the both of you develops the smell of something balsamic resinious. Almost enchanting.......

Suddenly you realize that it's all a memory of forgotten dreams. Forgotten dreams because the true reality hurts more than a lie. Holding on to the past makes no sence while you cuddle your first born. He smiles back at you in a very familair way.....
You swing the crib and then, out of nowhere, the curtains move as if a breeze came in and a so familiar smell fills the room while the windows are closed...it's the smell of Incubus which makes you wide awaken: the sensual and so powerful smell of leather makes you dizzy from desire. Incubus will be always a part of you even after he left...
"If suddenly
you forget me
do not look for me,
for I shall already have forgotten you"

- Pablo Neruda

Then it is dark. You sink deeper into the straw of your sleeping place, the resinous sheet in the barren chamber. You breathe in the scent of dark chocolate, still warm, poured over fermenting fruits that someone placed on your nightstand. It smelled of the smoke from the kitchen flames as you tiredly devoured it for sleep, then everything became a confused cotton, your eyes turned to stone as the room still spun.
Now the smoke glimmers like from tobacco leaves, the edges sharp green, like from damp grasses, you feel the presence of animalistic beings and hallucinate flowers, fleshy and waxy, growing on green spices. Over everything lies a fog that intoxicates the senses, the resins, the wood smoke, the chocolate liqueur. Is this all just a strange dream, or is an incubus present, a demon?
Now the damp meadows are on fire, the fruits, the flowers, the spices are scorching, smoke billows through the room in ethereal sharpness, rain hisses as it extinguishes the smoldering ash and washes the thoughts, the vivid dreams into moist, green, burnt earth.
**
With "Incubus," Nikolay Eremin created a dynamic scent image that remarkably does justice to its theme. The demon of hypnagogic illusion, who mates with a sleeping woman at night without her noticing, initially captivates with a strong yet incredibly balanced blend of resins, bitter chocolate liqueur, tobacco, and wood smoke, which soon gives way to slightly animalistic musk, a waxy-fleshy tuberose, and bitter spices. Vetiver provides sharp contours, appearing both smoky and damp. After about an hour, one truly believes in the presence of the incubus, as the smoke and ash seem so ethereal, almost sulfurous in a positive sense. The visitation fades after about six hours into earthier tones.

(With thanks to Chizza)

Fresh, cool, slightly damp wood. Natural and urban. Melancholic and robust. For breathing and dressing. Reminds me of Paul Schütze's 'Behind the rain', but less green, less dark, less synthetic. A slightly brighter version. Without sourness. Essentially a mineral-woody scent, permeated by the elements, like a gray dry stone on which the last water remnants silently evaporate, complemented by a wonderfully aromatic pine-cypress ether with - almost soft - green nuances. This uniqueness is further enhanced by a subtly used incense that gives it depth and a touch of mystery. Just like the somewhat sweeter resins myrrh and elemi, which increase wearability with this quality. Everything is incredibly finely tuned, wonderfully restrained without being shy. Radiating a worship-worthy lightness despite its seriousness. An effortless elegance. This composition comes close to Giacobetti's transparent-sensitive masterpieces like 'En Passant' or 'L'Original'. Lyn Harris' less is more style of absolute calmness, simplicity, and lightness, as well as the so soothing renunciation of popular, modern, eternally lasting, and often unpleasantly smelling synthetic components in the drydown, is showcased here par excellence. More expressive due to the "heavyweight" ingredients than much of her still relatively young brand. And yet, I can't imagine that this idea can be composed more effortlessly. For me, one of her best works.

review_title: I Prefer to Go Out in the Rain.
review_content:
The name of this fragrance immediately caught my attention. I am a total nature person! I love being outside in any weather; no mood of the weather can ruin my spirits. So I enjoy rain just as much as sunshine. My favorite place is in the woods, so the scent combination of rain and wood is not entirely foreign to me.

I was lucky enough to participate in a sharing right away (thank you for that!).
When the sample arrived, I could hardly wait, and upon the first sniff from the bottle, I thought only "wow!", authentic rain. So I sprayed it immediately. Even then, an intense clear scent of rain. For me, it’s more rain on asphalt than on wood, but very accurate! Yet even here, I smell a subtle floral note that I really don’t like. However, it is so inconspicuous that I hope it will be fine.

Unfortunately, it does not fit. The rain scent disappears incredibly quickly (not even 20 minutes), and what remains is this totally unpleasant floral-sweet note. Is it the angelica, or the water lily? I don’t know. I just know that I don’t like it. It somehow smells oppressive to me. The scent that lingers is quite weak, but you know how it is, when you don’t like something, no matter how subtle it is, it just bothers you...

So, unfortunately, Rain Wood has disappointed me. It gives a promise upon the first sniff that it cannot keep. If the rain scent didn’t fade so extremely quickly, I would say it’s just a matter of taste whether one likes this floral note or not - but the fact that the scent has nothing to do with rain after half an hour is really a shame.
My boyfriend also tested it and reported a similar experience: the rain scent fades quickly, and for him, it then became floral-sweet, but later turned a bit more bitter. But he is not convinced either. What a pity!
I don’t know what it is; after all, people here have had good experiences with the scent. Maybe it just doesn’t like my skin very much.

So my sample will have to move on, and I’ll just wait for the real rain :)

[Edit: The review was indeed incomplete until just now, due to technical difficulties - I assume it makes more sense now. :D]

Very nice scent that actually reminds me of a rainy forest floor. The fragrance reminds me of something from the past. It could be Sumatra Rain by Axe (the deodorant of my youth 20 years ago), but I can't be sure about that. Unfortunately, the sillage is not particularly strong, so it's more of a scent for personal relaxation.

it's cool in the forest, the dew drops sparkle on the moss
it's quiet in the forest, you hear the leaves rustling,
calm and proud, almost unattainable, the bright trunks reach into the sky
it smells of clean air, clear water, herbs, and hidden flowers.
seemingly quite simple .....and yet it is a highly refined composed perfume.
lasting, refreshing, clarifying, noble.
it has a clarity and tranquility that becomes more valuable with each wear.

"Art is concentrated nature"

review_title: Little Fire in the Pine Forest?
review_content:
Or just the small incense burner in the bathroom when you're sitting in a bath with pine needle oil?

The latter is certainly the safer and cozier association. I do enjoy coniferous perfumes, and therefore this one has my sympathy as well. Among the 4 fragrances from the brand that I get to test in the travel note, it is also the most expressive and the longest-lasting on my skin, which is why it gets a comment from me as the only one.

At the beginning, the impression of conifer resin is so strong that I perceive it as almost camphor-like freshness, but apparently no one else has chosen the classification "fresh" so far. The bright and rather cool-looking incense makes its appearance a bit later, but it remains clearly subordinate to the coniferous notes. An absolutely unsweetened, autumnal perfume, probably more of a candidate for leisure time.

Anyone who likes woody-smoky perfumes should take the risk of a test! For me, the only potential purchase candidate from the series.

absolute feel-good fragrance. It is so wonderfully calming and protective that I really associate Namasté with a peaceful yoga session with meditation, preferably in a clearing in the middle of a coniferous forest. The pine note here is really very, very subtle, in my opinion. It is more of a homogeneous composition of fewer noble ingredients, appearing complex, deep, warming, and yet gently fresh. Overall, it has a slightly ethereal quality, and fresh grasses are also perceptible. I keep looking at the fragrance notes because I feel like something is missing there. Somehow, there is a soft component as a base in the scent, perhaps a hint of patchouli or musk? It reminds me a little of "Thundra" in the drydown. Overall, it’s a fragrance perfect for wrapping yourself up in. The sillage on my skin is subtle, and the longevity is about 7 hours. A quiet presence, but one that can still stand out with its constantly emanating pleasant scent. I give it an absolute recommendation for testing!

I must confess, I only got this perfume because it was incredibly cheap, I already own a few La Rive scents and think very highly of them.
Unfortunately, there was no tester and the fragrance went blindly into my shopping cart.
At home, being as curious as I am, I immediately unpacked it and sprayed it on.
Well, then came the shock, ..........Bruno Banani. To me, it smells exactly like Bruno Banani "woman", maybe not quite as intense, but unmistakably so. Anyone who knows these fragrances knows that they all resemble each other very closely and have that typical Bruno Banani scent, the one from the pink bottle. I even believe that this one always serves as the "base ingredient" for all the other variations, and then a few other "ingredients" are mixed in, and voilà, we have a new Banani.
I have nothing against these fragrances, as I think they have an extremely high recognition value, last very well with great sillage.
Unfortunately, I belong to those who overindulged in Bruno during school days and emptied quite a few bottles. Now something inside me blocks when I just smell it.
However, as I said, it is a very individual scent and offers a great price-performance ratio.
"Bueno," on the other hand, does not have great sillage and the longevity leaves much to be desired. I can hardly perceive it shortly after spraying it on. Now and then I notice it again, but it's not worth mentioning.
In my opinion, everyone would be better off with the original in this case, as it is not significantly more expensive but offers more in terms of scent, longevity, and sillage.
I also read online that "Bueno" is supposed to smell similar to Banani "Magic," which I cannot confirm, as I have never sniffed that one; for me, it definitely smells like Banani and very much like the one in the pink bottle.

I have 2 Montale selections and they both serve one very specific purpose - nostalgia for the 1990s and that is it. When I was on the cusp of turning 40, I bought several 1990s to early 2000s era frags for the magic of olfactive scent memory and feel nostalgia for younger, more care free, and quite plainly for my life experience, more fun times.

Did they do the trick? I suppose, albeit in a lesser fashion than I’d imagined they would. My nose felt they were less than they had been - be it the quality of oils used, IFRA changes that occured and necessitated altered formulations, or simply watered down offerings due to the frags being selections that had gone through multiple reformulations in the years since they’ve fallen out of fashion en masse. Tommy, Hugo, The Dreamer, Dunhill Desire Blue were all standbys in my teen years rotation. Sculpture was one I didn’t personally own, but I knew several that had it and would “borrow” some sprays from time to time.

Enter Montale’s Fougeres Marines and Wood & Spices. Off the top Fougeres just hits my nose like a 90s one two pinch of Tommy and Hugo. At opening much more Tommy and into dry down sort of an equal mix of the two. I’d heard / seen several compare Wood & Spices to Sculpture, The Dreamer, and Desire Blue and to my nose I get equal parts of all of those.

I don’t wear either of them often and while I’ve got several fbs from the sister company, Mancera, and enjoy those quite a bit, I have not, and don’t plan on delving deeper into Montale. They hit their sweet spot for me and there they shall remain within my fragrance wardrobe, no more, no less.

If you, too, are looking for that 90s nostalgia but from a brand that offers options that project and last as long as I would imagine one could desire, and don’t want thinner or watered down versions, while being willing to pay a tad more in line with what those 90s frags went for back in those days, this may hit that sweet spot.

I enjoy the heck out of some of my more refined niche frags, but I can also appreciate these for what they are. I say that because I know Pierre Montale’s works can spark “controversy” within the fragrance community. To some they’re just a synthetic mess, to some they’re an affordable gateway to niche, to some they’re absolutely outstanding. I appreciate them for what they are. Some of my Manceras I can’t imagine parting with. Are they going to hit my nose like Roja, Royal Crown, Stéphane Humbert Lucas, Francesca Bianchi, among others - no, certainly not. However, they do, at times and situationally hit my nose as simply perfecto for what my nose craves. These 2 fit the perfecto bill when I want that 90s feel and for that reason, I couldn’t imagine wanting to ever sell or trade them away. Sillage, Projection, and Longevity, like all Montale and Mancera I’ve experienced is about as potent as I could want. Refinement and quality of ingredients is lower spectrum of niche - they’re synthetic and not “natural ingredient” smelling, but they’re as good as it gets for doing what they do and what my expectations could be for their doing so.

I smelled it on my friend, and I was like wtf is that! it smells amazing, fresh and inviting. earthy and green. its smells incredible, I see hugo by hugo boss down in the suggestions which happens to be one of my favorites. so If you like hugo, by hugo boss. we have a similar nose. this is right here will be worth a blind buy

By chance, I was offered Montale fougeres marine as a bargain. Apparently, my acquaintance didn't like it. After a first test, my clear classification is rather masculine, as it is marketed as a fragrance for men. But then a friend said, why shouldn't a woman wear this scent! After all, women have also embraced marine fragrances today. And so, for very little cash, I acquired an almost full bottle of FM from Montale.
My first impression, I've been wearing it for two days now, good longevity, 7 hours on me, a maritime freshness kick, a feel-good scent for a cool head, I smell mint, the distance it creates clarifies my emotional state, bringing me to calm.
It reminds me in scent expression of a mix between Allure Sport Homme and Davidoff Cool Water women. FM is very civilized for Montale, not overpowering, but rather pleasing in expression. It is well-suited for the masculine side in us women, namely to go through the day calmly, coolly, and distantly.

I had a bit of a hard time trying to describe this Montale fragrance, as I could hardly identify any note without knowing the details in the pyramid. My first impression was: Hm, is this Montale? Surely, there must be something similar that is cheaper and not niche (although one could debate whether Montale really falls under "niche"). The second thought: This is not unisex; it is clearly for men. The third: It smells somewhat synthetic, although I couldn't quite say why. It’s not an aquatic Calone that jumps out at you, nor is it the penetrating substance sometimes listed as ozone, but it is certainly not the true rough sea. Despite the slightly synthetic impression, this is, after all, the most pleasant and accurate interpretation of "sea water" that I have encountered so far. Admittedly, I don't really know much in this direction, which I will change when I get the chance.

An impressive freshness spreads from the very beginning. I don't perceive it as indefinably synthetic; it feels menthol-like, like very sharp mint, with a hint of squeaky sour lemon juice. This cool, bitter freshness is extremely pleasant and compensates for the somewhat chemical-seeming sea water. It actually reminds me of a brisk breeze on a very cool day during a walk on the beach, clearing your head.

The coastal vegetation definitely provides a lot of oak moss, because to my nose, there is far more "fern" than "marine" present here. I don't smell lavender at all, at least nothing I would recognize as such. Patchouli is at most perceptible as a very subtle hint if you look for it. I can easily find the geranium and musk on the paper strip (where the scent becomes much rounder), while on my skin, a mixture of sea water and moss dominates.

I used up 2 samples of this marine fougère with some enthusiasm when it was around 40 degrees in the shade during the summer. If the climate catastrophe should lead to such sweltering heat occurring more frequently, I will definitely get myself a whole bottle of refreshing sea water. Otherwise, I would clearly leave this scent to men and wouldn't mind if I came across it on one or another specimen.

First, thanks to Awin for the sample!

Fougères Marine. I was curious how Montale would interpret the blend of herb-green and aquatic. I usually find aquatic notes boring or they remind me of the scent of men's deodorant.

When first sprayed, I was a bit disappointed. The scent smelled strange.
But then the top note developed into a spicy freshness. Only very faintly could one perceive a subtle sweetness. Are all the ingredients listed here? I predominantly smell a fresh herbiness. I do not detect lemon. I wonder where the seawater is supposed to be? Was that the strange scent opening?

The heart note then develops a bit sweeter, but the summer character of the fragrance remains well preserved. The intensity is okay. The lavender wanders around in the heart undefined.

The base clearly has a fougère accord. Only the musk could have been toned down a bit, as there is a slight hairspray note in the dry down.

Conclusion: well done, but still not to my taste.

With an order from Montale, I was able to add a 20ml travel spray with a fragrance of my choice. I chose the Fougeres Marines. With its marine touch, I would say it’s not a typical Fougere scent. It’s an easy-to-wear, non-intrusive everyday fragrance. It wafts a fine fresh breeze around the nose. Certainly not a scent that has revolutionized the fragrance world, but quite...

... sitting on the beach with my feet in the sea on Sylt. A floral scent and something green comes from the island. From the sea, there’s a salty fresh aquatic note. Just tilt your head back and enjoy.

When the fragrance is applied, you get aquatic seawater and lavender, complemented by the green of moss and the freshness of patchouli. It is rounded off at the end by musk. The perfume has a fine masculine aura.

The longevity and sillage are good.

For those who like fresh and fougère scents, this is an interesting fragrance that is worth checking out.

I feel similarly to Igraine that FM gives a synthetic impression - this happens to me with almost all Montale fragrances.

After spraying, a citrus freshness becomes noticeable, which within a minute lets the mint come to the forefront.
Shortly thereafter, it develops into a sharp freshness, which, however, is overly overshadowed by a sweetness accompanied by menthol.

All in all, a very pleasant scent, although the sweetness can also be bothersome.

review_title: If there is coconut, this is a Malibu Cola!
review_content:
Nishane's Fan Your Flames is undoubtedly one of my favorites from the house, offering a boozy, rich, and indulgent experience. From the first spray, it immediately evokes the scent of rum and cola, blending a deep, sweet-ish, and spicy booziness.

If you're specifically looking for coconut, as it is listed in the notes... you will be disappointed. Instead, I can smell a realistic cola accord. In my opinion, this fragrance does it better than Enigma PARFUM, which leans more towards a cognac-heavy warmth rather than a true rum-and-cola feel. Fan Your Flames, by contrast, captures that perfect balance of sweetness and spice, making it more "fun" in the opening.

As it dries down, the composition evolves by bringing out a warm, mildly-smoky tobacco note.
There are faint similarities with "Honor & Glory | Lattafa / لطافة" in the later stages, particularly in the interplay of warm tobacco and woods. However, Fan Your Flames has a much more pronounced tobacco presence, which emerges more distinctly as the fragrance settles. Lataffa's fragrance plays more on the cinnamon & sandalwood accord.

Overall, this is perfect for cooler weather, nights out, or when you want something smooth. If you enjoy boozy, tobacco-laced (but not dominant) fragrances with a unique cola twist, this one is absolutely worth trying.

I am on the hunt for my personal holy grail tobacco fragrance and while researching the note of tobacco I came across the tantalizingly unique note profile of Fan your Flames from the highly regarded house of Nishane.

This is my first Nishane and was a total blind buy and as many have already stated, FYF is definitely not a safe blind buy. But before I was even able to get my nose on the scent I was very impressed by the packaging and unboxing experience that Nishane puts together and after my tobacco hunt cools down I am looking forward to further exploring this gorgeous house.

FYF immediately stood out to me due to the unique note combination of coconut and tobacco, both of which sit atop my favourite notes in perfumery. This alone was enough for me to smash the Add to Cart button and before long I had the first sprays of this firey fragrance on my wrist.

The opening is by far my favourite part of this fragrance. You are blasted with a warm and boozy toasted coconut. This is not a typical sunscreeny coconut but rather one that has been kissed by open flames and left to smolder. It's not smokey but warm, resinous and although slightly sweet, that sweetness is overpowered by a peppery herbaceousness. This opening is intense and projects well but despite its warmth, I strongly believe that the opening suits every season well. There is enough beachy campfire and coconut to capture the allure of the summer while also being paired with a comforting and boozy warmth that easily cuts through the cold winter air. Though the notes of tobacco and coconut initially seem like they would clash fairly strongly, there is no cacophony of competing notes trying to out loud the other. The blend is at its best in the opening and every note is incredibly well balanced and this allows FYF to appear effortlessly classy in spite of a more casual scent profile.

Like many great things, this does not last. Before I speak about my personal issues with the drydown I want to say that FYF's drydown is fairly linear, the overall scent profile really doesn't change much between initial spray and 10 hours in. The coconut fades into the background and the tobacco in the base becomes more prominent but besides that, all the notes remain more or less the same. However... the way that these notes combine with each other and the way the blend develops does not do this fragrance any favors. The well balanced nature I spoke of earlier does not remain for the entire life of this fragrance and on my skin, every note degrades and falls out of harmony the farther I get from the initial spray. What starts out as a warm, toasted coconut becomes a dirty, fleshy, sticky mess on my skin. It's as though some really cheap sugary coconut liquer was spilled onto an expensive cigar and the resulting liquid was left to dry on my skin. I really can't bring myself to appreciate this drydown no matter how many times I've tested this fragrance. It genuinely makes my skin feel like it hasn't been washed in days. The tobacco is there but it's mutated by this stale and sweaty syrupiness from the degradation of the top notes.

At its best, FYF projects a carefree confidence and makes me feel like I'm simultaneously vacationing in the tropics while also being inside a fancy humidor as winter winds pelt the outside of the room. The opening is truly a work of art and every single time I experience this I tell myself that this fragrance is a masterpiece and THIS is the time that the drydown will be different. Unfortunately that time hasn't come.

Despite my distaste for the drydown, I can't bring myself to rate FYF any lower than a 7.5. The opening is absolutely incredible and impeccably unique and I hope one day that the rest of this fragrances life will grow on me because it's clear that Nishane put a lot of work into crafting this scent. It may very well be a skin chemistry issue but it's an issue that makes FYF very difficult to wear for more than a few hours without feeling dirty. I wish I could get more from this fragrance, I can't overstate how captivating its opening is and it leaves me wanting more every time I wear this.

review_title: Pure fire and at the same time charm in a bottle
review_content:
"Do not feel lonely, the entire universe is inside you. Stop acting so small. You are the universe in ecstatic motion. Set your life on fire. Seek those who fan your flames."
Rumi, Persian Poet, 13th Century.
This is the quote by Rumi which inspired Nishane's Fan your Flame, an amazing (probably one of the best) perfumes I've ever smelled. A combination of coconut, tobacco and rum that gives a warm Caribbean touch to the sweetness of tonka bean and to the woodiness of Chinese cedarwood. Oakmoss completes the picture.
F.Y.F. is an extrait of parfum, this means that sillage and persistence are huge!

It's an unisex fragrance, in my opinion more masculine but it can suit women too without problems! This is why I decided to make myself a "little" gift and buy it, I just couldn't resist... I fell in love at first "sniff"
It's wild, pure fire, but at the same time charm in a bottle.
Preferably to be sprayed in autumn/winter because as I said, it's literally fire! HOT
The bottle is very elegant and it comes in a beautiful box with an amazing postcard. Well done Nishane!

This Rumi-inspired concoction has turned out to be a beautiful blind buy. I haven't tried any of the Nishane perfumes but am very impressed by the quality so far. The perfume is multi-faceted, long lasting and powerful. It starts off very tropical with pineapple and coconut. I wish there was more rum: here it is more like restrained sweet liquor whereas I would have liked more punch, like a rum raisin.
