The tang of cedarwood makes the intense sweetness bearable but you have to like super sweet perfumes in the style of Tabacca, Or du Serail and Sacre Tabac Sucree. For those that like hookah/shisha perfumes, you will love this.

review_title: Set your life on fire. Seek those who fan your flames
review_content:
"Set your life on fire. Seek those who fan your flames."
- Rumi

New York, sitting in a bar with a fireplace, smoking a good coconut-flavored hookah and tasting rum.
This is the presentation postcard of Fan Your Flames.
The fragrance starts off immediately with a nice coconut edged with a boozy note: with a generous addition of pepper it would have been a very similar opening to Pazzaglia's Carbonara.
As time passes, the alcoholic hint wanes and a good, non-cherry, fairly dry tobacco takes over.
In the drydown, oak moss gives smoky hints that combine well with the other notes and make the composition very intriguing and persistent.
This is a warm scent with exotic vibes, but not tropical beach; a contemporary metropolis scent.

review_title: A different take on the tobacco
review_content: This is me, I am a Pina Colada and I smoke cigars, good quality ones. I like to spend my time on the beach so I always apply sun tan lotion. I am addictive, intriguing sweet and classy. Spending time with me is a blessing and a curse, you love and hate me at the same time. One thing is for sure, you can't get bored with me. You like being around me because I fuel your...

Just like an artistic painting of ingredients but mysterious, it takes time to absorb it and enough space to reveal its contents. It's not the kind of fragrance you spray, inhale, and judge in a minute. A gritty, he leaves you in confusion until you get to the right perspective to see it, don't get too close or you clash with his heaviness, his cruelty and you don't walk away from him losing yourself in his pleasure. I find boozy notes to be one of the most seductive notes in perfumes, especially when we are talking about matured spirits like rum.
Fan Your Flames is inspired by Rumi, a Sufi poet known for his courageous and exploratory vision of religion and teachings, he inspired and instilled positivity through his serene messages laden with wisdom, but unlike Rumi, Fan Your Flames is dark and mysterious, in the best possible way. From the beginning I take tobacco and rum which make the opening spicy and intoxicating, there is coconut mentioned in the notes but I have almost none, although, I make myself a sweet and nutty undertone that could be due to the coconut. I love how it has held a smoky profile for so long, the combination of rum with a rich cedar smells like a finely aged rum joint, the luxurious and resinous tone is further enhanced by a very prominent tonka bean which adds a warm, creamy and nuttosa facet to woody drydown. There is a slight sweetness in the background throughout the journey, accompanied by a deliciously smoky tobacco.
It reminds me of a hookah bar I used to visit, going out with friends, drinking spilled on wooden tables, big smiles on our faces. What fun it was for a moment to watch the city lights fade into smoke and then shine again!

review_title: Boozy - woody - smoky, but not much coconut
review_content: This is a joint review of Fan Your Flames and Fan Your Flames X. Fan Your Flames is a rich, woody, spicy and boozy scent. Coconut was hardly there for me. There was a definite smoky or burnt type of accord. It has only a subtle sweetness. Quite masculine. Performance is very good - lasting well over 10 hours with strong sillage the first few hours. review_title: Are you wearing the fragrance or is it wearing you?
review_content:
This is a powerful one! Rum and cola with coconut, super spicy. So addictive and very bold. The note combination somehow turns leather-y for me, so if you´re not into that, be aware. Masculine leaning for sure, but still unisex if you can pull it off as a woman.

This one needs to be tested before buying.

review_title: A mixed drink next to a bonfire
review_content:
This is....wow.
You think your getting this woody spicy mix, but really the dry down is boozy & sweet. Coconut & rum is prominent, i won't go into these diatribes where I try to paint you any picture. But this is a date night/night out frag to be worn. Its thorough, long lasting and SEXY! Compliments for days!
This is clearly stated, a beautiful fragrance. I wouldn't wear it during the day, it's a night fragrance through and through. I'd say fall & winter, a cool spring evening. But im crazy enough to try this bad boy on a beautiful summer night while out at the bar or on a date. Why not? It FANS YOUR FLAMES

Smells really lik al Capone . This is not for kids but real men! Smells like scarface with his sigar . The rum and oakmoss in here makes it so good and so masculine. I wish the sillage was a bit stronger but it’s Oke . This fragrance , I can forgive Nishane for that. What a winner frag

review_title: An absolutely delicious coconut dipped boozy tobacco
review_content:
Fan your Flames is sweet, slightly velvety, and is very dry and dusty tobacco with creamy coconut-like nuances. It definitely smells like a party on a Pirate ship somewhere in between the ocean. I also get a lot of earthiness in the back which is very reminiscent of what I get in Sultan Vetiver. You can definitely sense that both the fragrances are from the same brand. ⁣
⁣
⭕ To me it's slightly masculine leaning due to the smokey/ earthy base I spoke about above but that doesn't mean that the ladies can't wear it. The sweetness really balances out everything atleast in the opening and really makes this fragrance another winner from the house for me. Also for the people who don't enjoy overly boozy fragrances, this could be a great start. ⁣
⁣
Overall, Fan your Flames is delicious Malibu coconut rum that's a delight to wear. It's tasty like a coconut-based cocktail, warm like the smoke from the bonfire, and slight green like the wind from the pine forest nearby. Can't go wrong. This is a huge recommendation from me

First time i smell and try this on my skin i didn't hesitate buy it at all.
If you're tobacco or Rum lover this is the one for you my nose didn't get much coconut but rum and tobacco stand out all the time that's make me fall in love more and more through time i'm wearing it. Longevity is really insane 9 hours+ just only 2 sprays.
When i wear it i fell like chill vibe on the beach smoke nice cigar and sip whiskey along with it.
Personally i suggest just try this you may fall in love such as i do

This really unique masterpiece is either love or hate at the first sight. I had two wonderful perfumes from Nishane already and I knew that the performance and the longevity are great. I was just again surprised how all those notes blend beautifully together. Nishane is a niche perfume house from Istanbul and their quality is 10/10

Because of the main accords which I like and an opinion of most of the people that this is well blended totally unique scent (plus hours ) made me pull the trigger as a blind buy. Anyway I recommend sample first.

Main accords: sweet, tobacco, coconut, woody (Chinese Cedar), rum, vanilla, mossy (Oakmoss)
What you get - or better what I got:
Forever lasting powerfull burnt smoky coconut rum experience and this perfume really is an experience. I love this! I was scared about tobacco note but it’s not like dirty smoked cigarette, it’s rather smoky airy feeling, pleasant one. Coconut is not cloying or sunscreen one, it’s burnt dry coconut. Tonka Beans gives it a little bit sweet hint while rum lingers in the background.

This is perfect for the wintertimes but I will definitely try it in fresh summer evenings as well while dreaming of being in the Pirates Of The Caribbean-movie. ️

Unisex, a bit male leaning, Fan Your Flame X is female version.
Longevity is eternal, a sillage is huge.

Nishane Fan Your Flames is a unique unisex fragrance with a mix of rum, tobacco, and fruity notes. It’s warm, rich, and sensual, making it perfect for any occasion, whether casual or special. The scent lasts long and is sure to make a lasting impression wherever you go. A bold and versatile choice. Go for it

Fan Your Flames is probably the most interesting and highest quality tobacco-coconut combo I’ve ever smelled. Upon first spray you’re blasted with this ultra-realistic tobacco note which is both nutty and delicious, paired with a deep, boozy rum accord and a coconut in the base
If you like those notes, you'll love this fragrance
As Always, not for a blind buy :)

review_title: The aftertaste of a party in the Caribbean
review_content:
This perfume is like the morning aftertaste of a cool party somewhere in the Caribbean, perhaps, where there is still a strong mixture of aromas of sweet alcohol, cigars, coconuts and thousands of burnt firecrackers and fireworks in the air. The note of fire/ gunpowder / barbecue / burnt matches in this perfume (a similar note that I also smell in some Imaginary Authors perfumes) is very dominant here, and sometimes it overshadows everything else in the composition for me....
Sooo, yesterday's party was obviously very hot! ;)

FAN YOUR FLAMES by nishane is a very masculine sell you got to be an alpha to wear this the rum the coconut the tobacco the cedar its crazy. it's rich is heavy its strong very good. you will make a statement with this perfume. its kind of like an more masculine more manly man version of jazz club by maison martin margiela replica line. only this adds the coconut in the mix wich is very good to be honest.

Summer day, or night, some drinks, some eye contact. It could set the mood. But we what I've smelled from Nishane now, there's an almost dirty quality. review_title: Coconut rum works in drinks, does it work as a scent...
review_content:
Checking out the scores, I feel a little out of place and guilty because this isn't going to go good, but what am I other than just one voice of the many who enjoy this scent. Definitely worth a sample if you are interested as Nishane is typically very good in the quality category.

This one comes off very coconut and boozy forward, as if I spilled a pretty famous coconut flavored rum on me. It's loud and in your face at first spray but mellows quickly. I don't find this to be all that good for my tastes, but I will say the notes are accurate when people remark on the coconut and rum. It transitions to a somewhat sweeter tobacco note with some coconut still lingering about. I seem to get some woodiness and even moss on the dry down.

I am not a fan of this. I think the coconut might be throwing me off? I am not sure. If you like this kind of scent, I don't know if anything could beat it.

If I want rum, I might reach for Jazz Club (for example), if I want tobacco, I might reach for Herod (for example), if I want everything plus coconut, this could be your jam. It's not mine.

I actually wonder how good this could be to my nose minus the coconut. Now that would be awesome, I think.

Perfume that smells like the Cuban national gem - Havana Club rum mixed with coconut oil in the accompaniment of tobacco (probably twisted into a cigar-shaped on Kubanek thighs) seasoned with tonka beans and decorated with the scent of green moss and cedar (this time Chinese cedar - pink - called Cedrela) .
An interesting experience I associate with heat, sun, warm sea (be it the Caribbean or an island in the ocean), a pipe in my hand and smoke in my mouth (as I still smoked) and a glass of coconut rum with ice cubes and the smell of conifers coming from the land. I think that some people may associate it with the smell of shisha - yes, it's a good comparison.
Although I associate it with warmth, summer, peace and relaxation, I believe that it is a competitor for winter - warming with its warmth, positive vibration, bliss and light sweetness. Personally, I also see him on a woman more than a man, although in winter I like to humiliate him and… .. make a quick trip to another part of the world and at a different time of the year.
I recommend it especially to women, including fans of such fragrances as Carner-Palo Santo, Montale-Honey Aoud, MEMO-Shams Oud, Mancera-Red Tobacco.
Very good projection, durability - up to 12 hours (it is really very durable).

A much talked about early release from Turkish house Nishane, of which I have only ever tried Rosa Turca. The note pyramid intrigued me on this and I was keen to see if the actual smell delivered. Thank you.

review_title: The Gentlemen-Pirate from the South Istanbulian Islands
review_content:
Rum, coconut, and tobacco in a perfume, with cedar as a base? Have my years of pleading to a higher power been answered?

I have relatively high expectations when it comes to rum and tobacco - I have been dealing with R(h)um for many years and was previously in the tobacco industry.

So it was clear to me in advance - either this is my long-awaited holy grail, or I will stop searching and dedicate myself to, for example, a model railway or start sewing children's clothes.

One must give credit to Nishane, the presentation, packaging, and bottle are incredibly elegant and beautifully displayed. This is enjoyable.

The scent opens quite smoky right away, a resinous smoke with a hint of sweetness - it reminds me of a smoky, natural oud that I once had the chance to sniff. Then a lovely coconut joins in, very nutty and natural, the sweetness is moderate. No coconut milk, no Bounty, but really well done. Cedar & rum create an open rum barrel - aromatic, authentic, sharp, and dark. Anyone who has ever stood in a warehouse with rum barrels will remember this now.

The tobacco is green-herbaceous and heavy, swirling powerfully around the rum barrel, while the coconut shells crackle on the fire. Every now and then - a resinous-sweet-smoky note flashes, reminiscent of hashish. The progression is truly wonderful, the scent constantly shifts, and a new olfactory impression comes in all the time. It feels very high quality overall.

Longevity is phenomenal, easily 12h+. One should not overdo it - as always - since the sillage quickly rises to a few meters. Two sprays from the hefty bottle are sufficient.

Fan your Flames is exotic, a bit wicked, and carries a certain lustfulness - at the same time, it is just as distinguished and possesses a certain nobility. Gentlemen-Pirate sounds terribly clichéd, but somehow it is apt.

This perfume will certainly have a permanent place in my collection. I am still searching for the holy grail ;-)

review_title: Caribbean Party in the Ruhr Area
review_content:
Recently, I had a silly accident while doing my weekend shopping. Before you gasp in shock: I had already bought butter and salami, all good. No, my lovely wife wanted to bring the vacation vibe home despite Corona. Instead of beach, palm trees, and sea, it was party cellar with dim lighting, Dortmund Union beer, and homemade Raffaello schnapps from the bathtub. From my friend, Jürgen.

Sounds good, right? Well, anyway, my wife sent me out again to buy coconuts and Caribbean stuff. No problem, I'm a pro at that! I can boast several stays at Caribbean resorts. Quickly put on my Halston Z-14. After Googling, I bought rum. The one from the middle shelf. Not too cheap but also not an expensive drop, she wouldn't taste the difference anyway. While I was there, I grabbed a couple of packs of cigarettes and some vanilla liqueur. Jürgen swears by it.

Then the mishap happened as I was leaving the store. The stone slabs outside were too slippery for my flip-flops (I had already put on my vacation outfit as a precaution), I slipped, balanced my shopping but it was no use. I crashed down and everything spilled over me. First, the coconuts spilled out along with the rum. I suddenly smelled like Klaus Störtebeker, I tell you! Anyway, the rum was quite intense and very alcoholic, phew! Only now did I realize that a bit of tobacco and vanilla liqueur had fallen into the spilled coconut-rum mix. Well, that didn't make much of a difference. The rum already tasted very sweet because of the coconut. As pleasant as the scent was at first for a bad boy like me, it was a bit bothersome now. Quickly gathered the opened pack of cigarettes and headed to the car. Stupid that my mossy Halston no longer came through and also stupid that I partially fell into the cedar planting. As Andy Brehme once said: if you have shit on your foot, you have shit on your foot.

I drove home and smelled like an entire Caribbean bar, where you drink rum from a coconut shell. You probably think that's nonsense. Oh no! I've done that in Duisburg before! And it was really Caribbean, as the owner told me. And what Peter says is true. He was once married to someone from there. Twenty years ago. I was glad that all the other nonsense didn't also play into the scent. The alcoholic smell also weakened over time, it became sweeter and sweeter, but now the cigarettes also stank!
I parked my car and of course ran into my neighbor, that nasty Schofel! "All good, Captain Morgan?" he grinned at me. I wanted to tell him off but he was also lifting weights at home. So I smiled at him instead and pretended to be clumsy by dropping the keys to the front door several times. The idiot!
Anyway, I got home and told my wife about the mishap, she had already put on the grass skirt and the crown in her hair. She didn't quite get the hip swing right. She thought it wasn't a big deal and so everything was okay. I first opened a Union beer to calm down. She said to me, I'm not Jack Sparrow but still her pirate. To which I replied, she's not the woman from the Batida de Coco ad but for me, she's the drunk alternative. That didn't go over well. Maybe I inhaled too much of the rum smell.
That was my story! Good night from the sofa, folks!

review_title: Where Coconut, Rum, and Smoke Meet
review_content:
It was a warm summer evening when I first applied “Fan Your Flames.” I still vividly remember how the sun slowly sank behind the rooftops of the city, bathing the streets in a golden light. I had discovered the fragrance in a small perfumery-a narrow, dark bottle with golden accents that radiated something mysterious. The salesperson simply smiled when I asked how the scent was and said, “You have to find out for yourself.”

Barely applied, the top note unfolded: a sweet, warm wave of coconut and rum that instantly evoked a feeling of coziness and adventure at the same time. It was as if I held a small piece of summer in my hand: sweet, slightly intoxicating, and with a hint of wanderlust. I closed my eyes and could imagine sitting on a beach, my feet in the sand, a gentle breeze on my face, while the sun kissed the horizon.

But the fragrance was much more than just summer. After a few minutes, the heart note opened up: tobacco and tonka bean. Now the scent became deep, smoky, almost a bit mysterious. It told stories of long evenings with friends, of conversations by candlelight, of memories that linger like smoke in the air. Every breath felt like a step into a world full of warmth and familiarity, but also full of adventure.

Finally, the base note of oak wood, vanilla, and musk brought everything together. It gave the fragrance stability and depth, making it sensual, enveloping, and unforgettable. I could feel the hours the scent lingered on my skin, like a constant companion throughout the evening. People around me noticed it without me saying a word. It was subtle yet present, and it seemed as if everyone who came near me took a piece of this story with them.

In the following days, I wore the fragrance for special moments: at a dinner with friends, on a walk through the city at sunset, even during a spontaneous visit to a small, hidden bar. Every moment became more intense, more memorable, as if the fragrance extended time itself. “Fan Your Flames” was more than a perfume-it was an experience, a little journey that one could always carry with them.

Since that evening, the scent has become inseparable from warmth, a sense of adventure, and the feeling that every moment, no matter how small, can be special. Every time I smell it, I am reminded of that golden city, the setting sun, and the magic that arises when all the elements of sweetness, smoke, wood, and musk harmonize perfectly.

review_title: Away from the Hype, I Feel Your Fiery Temperament
review_content:
Sweet scents here and there, as far as the eye can see. Those who seek will find. Only what I am looking for I cannot find, at least not in the way I wished. Too much that has been too sweet for me lately, too much mainstream, few authentic gourmands, and then more and more flankers of well-known fragrances trying to adapt to the newer taste of the masses. Aventus was the holy grail for newcomers, slowly fading and increasingly hated. The tip of the iceberg. But everyone should have noticed who wears this fragrance. Therefore, a new grail was sought. It seemed that Baccarat Rouge 540 would be the next one. Much hyped, even more fragrances still trying to find similarities with saffron to then shine through differences.

Do I want that? NO, definitely not.
Even Baccarat Rouge 540 could not convince me. Especially not Aventus with the batches I tested. Everything felt so uniform, so conjured, and so boring. Especially BR540 was just sweet, sweet, and sweet for me. Exploded hairspray. Why? Do you just want to blend into the masses, to prove to some people that you wear something everyone wears and what many might perceive positively through good memories?

What is wrong with experimenting? Finding something that not everyone wears or that doesn't fit into the current hype. That is what makes it so exciting when you stand out, when you smell different. Here, interest and curiosity arise.

I currently feel this with my long-loved Spicebomb. The pepper no longer appeals to my nose. Too boring, too overused is the DANN. That is why Infrared seems to be doing so well. More than a reinterpretation of the known.
In the search, several candidates come into question. Many push themselves forward, even those that have already left my collection. I could perceive the fresher version of a Spicebomb in Histoires de Parfum's 1899. Good, but too close to the original. Even Ani by Nishane couldn't resist a bit of Spicebomb DNA. But in a more eccentric and stronger version. What a powerhouse.

No, it should be something completely different, something that is also demanding, perhaps not immediately cuddly, but striking. Here comes Nishane Fan Your Flames into play. Completely differentiated from the spicy-sweet mass of winter fragrances. Hints of a summer scent, nuances of a gourmand. Not a fragrance that precisely fits my requirements, but rather takes a supportive place in my collection.
It fascinates me, though. Complex, with edges and corners, a crazy all-rounder.

Summer?
Winter?
Who cares!

Initial coconut rolls through the campfire and bursts. Sniffing the woody coconut shell, the frayed remnants reaching, smoke rising, slightly charred. Nutty, woody, and coconut water in the sun. Smoky, it cools the skin to intensely distribute light smoky wisps. Nutty-fruity after slightly unripe coconut. The curse of the Caribbean. Rum, oh so.
A bit of alcohol can never hurt, as it dampens the excesses of the burnt shell. Is someone smoking here?
Lovingly wrapping ripe tobacco leaves. Not lit, just lying on the table, staring into the fire.

In summer, cooling on the skin, summer and vacation feeling ready. Caribbean islands full of warmth and cocktails under the little umbrella.
In winter, warming, smoky, coconut water in the wind.

The scent lingers on me for a long time. At least ten hours are in it. You don't radiate as extremely as others of your kind, but enough to envelop myself in your delicate notes.

What more could I want?
The search continues, perfection is not yet achieved, but this one has earned its place; my collection is happy about your participation.

review_title: only 7.1% of the owners are women? - I don't understand!
review_content: Dear ladies, if you are looking for a subtle, cuddly, sweet, slightly bitter but also mature scent, here it is! With a sweet and delicious coconut note that feels slightly tipsy due to the rum (Drunken Bounty?), accompanied by a soft and warm tonka bean that comes across confidently and maturely thanks to the tobacco and cedar. Definitely a recommendation for the ladies but...

Tobacco, rum, and coconut - all fragrance notes that I love. You can't go wrong with tonka bean either. There's nothing to complain about a nice cedar note. So it sounds like the perfect scent for me, and it was immediately added to my wish list.
After only a short time in the souk, I saw it and bought the whole bottle blindly. A few days later, it arrived at my place, very nice packaging, and I also like Nishane's postcard idea; it's something different. The bottle is designed very classically and only stands out because of its more unusual cap, which I like.
Well, let's get to the scent itself. As mentioned, I approached it with very high expectations due to the listed notes, and what can I say, you get what it says on the label. It starts with a strong and pleasant rum accord. However, after a short time, the coconut takes over, and the rum retreats to the background, replaced by cedar and tobacco. After a few hours, it's really just coconut and cedar with a smoky undertone. The longevity and sillage are also good. The scent had everything it promised, but unfortunately, I don't quite like the notes in this combination. The woody note is also, unfortunately, too pronounced for me in this fragrance. I guess I'll have to wait a bit longer until it gets warmer, and I can enjoy coconut in summery scents.
Nevertheless, it's a beautiful and, above all, unusual fragrance that one can certainly try.

review_title: Set your life on fire. Seek those who FAN YOUR FLAMES
review_content: Said the Sufi grandmaster, Jalal ad-Din al-Rumi. Nishane seems to imply a subtle reference to the mysticism of the Mevlevis here. Rumi is known to all of us? I hope so :) If not, here’s a little summary: Like almost every dervish, Rumi also "traveled" a lot. "Die to be born. Go to arrive." defines the phenomenon of traveling. His travels cover more than 4000 km: From his...

Since Nishane is currently one of my favorite brands, I had to test Fan your Flames. Luckily, it’s not as hyped as other fragrances from this house. What do you do when you want to test something? Of course, you immediately order a whole bottle! After all, we are environmentally friendly and want to reduce plastic waste from plastic sprayers :) However, my first...

I join all the pirate comparisons of my predecessors, and I think it’s great that I can! This fragrance truly combines many scent notes that must not be missing in a good pirate fantasy: boozy rum, coconut, a bit of sweetness, wood, tobacco, smoke, leather, green notes, and a very fine mustiness.

Malibù - Party in the Bay for really hearty people.

[The fragrances don’t have much in common aside from coconut and a boozy note, but they effectively represent the two ends of a Caribbean fantasy spectrum.]

Or better: People who wear Fan Your Flames ambush those who wear "Malibù - Party in the Bay | Simone Andreoli."

Or: People who wear Fan Your Flames turn a stiff beach party with piña coladas into a wild rum feast.

What do I like about the fragrance?

1. The scent is strong and multifaceted. In fact, the first minutes are very boozy, green, bitter, and somewhat unappealing. Since it was a blind buy for me, I briefly felt a certain regret. Only over time do coconut, tobacco, sweetness, and finer woody notes develop for me, making the fragrance really good, pleasant, and even a little elegant - although the scent should feel most at home in casual leisure. Additionally, I personally detect a slightly leathery note: the oak moss shows clear edges but harmonizes excellently with the other fragrance components.

2. The fragrance stimulates the imagination, and we associate heavier, bitter-spicy scent notes with sun, beach, and sea. Pirates in the Caribbean, indeed.
This breaks a tiresome cliché: with heavy, dark, gourmand, or spicy fragrances, direct connections are often made to winter wonderlands, Christmas markets, fireplaces, or other cold-romantic scenarios. This annoys me, and Fan Your Flames shows that it’s all in the mind and that classic notions can be questioned. Of course, one should take care of oneself and one’s environment regarding heavier fragrances in higher temperatures.

3. Pirates!

As the name suggests, Nishane Istanbul is a Turkish niche house (the only one!) that was founded in 2012 and gained some visibility by presenting its line at the Milan fair Esxence in 2015. The brand offers only perfumes in concentrated extract. It evokes a bold and extravagant scent, indeed passionate and ignited, as the name suggests, a gourmet tobacco that does not shy...

review_title: A Bar in Grenada with the Specialty "Coconut Rum"
review_content: Fan your flames, described as Jack Sparrow's scent. However, I see this on a completely different character from the "Pirates of the Caribbean" series: Elizabeth, the exceedingly beautiful noblewoman who becomes a cunning pirate herself throughout the series. The fragrance opens with a woody-dark coconut note but quickly shifts to rum. This truly delivers on its promise:...

First of all: I loooove boozy scents… And since the colder days have already caught up with us, it’s not even a crime to wear them during the day. This Nishane is wild. If Jack Sparrow had a signature scent - this is what he would wear! It smells like a pirate crew throwing a rum party on the beach and burning coconuts. Fan Your Flames by Nishane opens with a really...

Although Johnny likes to promote the Ambroxan bomb Sauvage in the real world, his fictional character has a different favorite: Fan your Flames. At first, the powerful rum note overwhelmed me a bit during my first sniff and pushed the notes of tobacco, tonka bean, and coconut into the background. This was disappointing for me, as I had been looking forward to these fragrance notes when I ordered it.

But I didn't want to give up on it. I kept returning to Fan your Flames, sniffing it, and over time I began to warm up to the strong rum note. After several sniffs, my nose could now also detect the other fragrance notes, albeit more subtly. Although the rum note is consistently dominant and perhaps not typical for summer or spring scents, Fan your Flames definitely shines on mild summer evenings.

I have had Fan Your Flames in my collection for quite a while now and have had the pleasure of wearing the scent extensively.
In fact, I have not smelled anything comparable so far, which makes this fragrance absolutely unique in my eyes.
It starts off with a hefty dose of coconut that has been soaked in rum. Personally, I love this opening, as it doesn’t come across as creamy sweet like a typical coconut, which gives it a more masculine touch. In my opinion, the scent progresses quite linearly, which is absolutely brilliant in this case, as this composition simply fits together beautifully. The sillage and longevity are well above average, so one should apply Fan Your Flames with care. I enjoy wearing this fragrance all year round, especially in the evenings and at celebrations.

So, if you want a unique scent that definitely stands out and garners compliments, you can't go wrong with Fan Your Flames!

review_title: First-Class Rum with an Unsweetened Raffaelo
review_content:
I stumbled upon the fragrance on Parfumo. When I saw the notes, I was very excited, but I didn't want to get it as a blind buy and in the distant future, as I have already spent a lot of money on fragrances lately :D
Spontaneously, I went with a friend to a new perfumery in Zurich and lo and behold: They happened to have FAN YOUR FLAMES in stock. Of course, I had to test it, and it was love at first spray. Naturally, I had to order it as soon as I got home!

For me, the scent is hard to place in a specific situation. It can be worn elegantly (not with a suit, but rather Casual Business), but I also see myself wearing it in the evening somewhere on the beach in shorts during a walk or at an outdoor bar. Personally, it is the best rum fragrance I have tested so far. At first, the coconut might be a bit too strong for some noses, but I like it, and in the drydown, it becomes pleasant and smooth for everyone. Longevity is easily a whole day (at least 9h), sillage is quite decent but not exaggerated. I can recommend this fragrance to anyone who takes life easy and achieves their goals solidly with the principle of minimalism. Nothing can bring you down!

So, if you like coconut and are looking for an alcoholic fragrance: FAN YOUR FLAMES is the perfect choice!

review_title: Pirates of the Caribbean Signature Scent
review_content: I can't help it... I see the ingredients coconut, rum, tobacco and I immediately imagine a pirate in the Caribbean wearing this perfume as his signature scent. In fact, the opening consists of a musty alcohol note that leans slightly towards the synthetic direction, and I think of a ragged pirate with missing teeth, pressing his saber to my throat and shouting at me because...

First of all: I only write reviews for fragrances that truly impress me in an extraordinary way. So why is this the case with Fan your Flames?

From the first spray, I was immediately surprised. I've never smelled anything like this. Cough drop in smoke, coconut in the background. Not the coconut you expect, but somehow minty, fresher coconut. Extreme contrasts right from the first sniff. It could also be a fresh sauna infusion. In the sauna, I see incense sticks blowing their flags into the sky while the visitors joyfully enjoy the best rum. Indefinable yet so clear (nonsensical) images. Contrasts indeed. Contrasts that don’t fit into my world but are incredibly attractive because of that.
Despite the strong smoky note, Fan your Flames is an absolute clean scent, something I've never experienced elsewhere.

What I find so brilliant about this fragrance happens more at the beginning; in the drydown, after about 4 hours, the smoke, which is rather unspectacular and too strong, remains while the wonderful unique freshness slowly fades away.

I don’t care, I want to own this fragrance. So unique, so mysterious, so clean, so wearable, so noticeable, so strong yet so pleasant, so crazy, so full of contrasts and as chaotic as this comment. This fragrance is incredibly complex.

Let’s go outside and smoke a cigar in front of the cocktail bar that has just burned down and was extinguished with coconut liqueur!

Sillage & Longevity:

The special aura surrounds me, as mentioned, for about 4 hours before it transforms into smoky wood. However, the little fire that this fragrance ignites is still clearly perceptible after 8 hours.

One last thing to say:
I want you! The 4 hours are worth it to me.

Fan your Flames has been with me almost since day one of my perfume journey. Back then, I received a sample of this fragrance, and it was the best scent I had smelled up to that point.

Coconut notes usually appear in summer fragrances like Miami or "White on White | XerJoff." However, Fan your Flames tries something new and transforms it into a perfect boozy winter scent with the perfect dose of rum, so it doesn't come off as too alcoholic. The nutty sweet aroma of the rum shines through nicely but not too strongly. The tonka bean enhances the sweetness and rounds it off. And the combination with my favorite note, tobacco, completes the fragrance into a masterpiece, adding spice and a hint of the Orient. Additionally, the oak moss also contributes a touch of spice to this composition. In my opinion, the sour tree note does not come through, which is a good thing, as I believe a green note would be disruptive here. The fragrance may be too sweet for some people since there is a sweet ingredient in the second tier of the notes pyramid. For my taste, it strikes the perfect balance of sweetness and spice. Highly recommended!

A new acquisition of mine. Fan Your Flames by Nishane has been on my radar for a while. The unique notes of coconut and rum seemed very appealing and exciting as a change for the collection. Many Nishane fragrances can be found at a good price, which wasn't the case before. This one, for example, can be partially found for 120 euros for 100ml. The MSRP for 50ml is already significantly more expensive. Definitely worth checking out, as this brand simply offers quality, performs excellently, and many just resonate really well.
Fan Your Flames is somewhat more edgy, especially due to the striking rum note in the first two hours. The coconut is also quite unique and something that may not appeal to everyone. You should definitely test it before purchasing, especially the opening could be quite off-putting in a blind buy. As it develops, it becomes much more pleasant and softer.

The bottle and Nishane packaging is, as always, a 10/10 for me. Simply elegant & luxurious. For me, it's among the best in the niche world. Not too much, not too little.
Fan Your Flames is a dark coconut scent. Those expecting Raffaello will be disappointed, especially at the start. A strong boozy rum note greets you there. It packs a punch and can be quite overwhelming for some. When smelled closely, it has a slightly musty vibe. In the air and from a distance, it's fine. Coconut is also present in the opening, but still overshadowed by the rum. As the rum note softens, the coconut develops beautifully and offers a lovely cocktail feeling, especially with this light cigar-tobacco note and wonderful creamy-sweet tonka that pairs great with the coconut. However, the scent never becomes overly sweet. The development is really well crafted, as this fragrance becomes pleasantly appealing without becoming too ordinary or mainstream. The base comes in very softly with a lot of cedar, and the heart notes of tonka & tobacco are still present. The woody-soft cedar base is excellent for the dry-down and a great finish.
Performance is, like all Nishanes, simply grand and worthy of an extrait. The rum opening is quite intense, and even in the further coconut development, the sillage is really good. The cedar base is still well noticeable and pleasant. Perfect for people who want to stand out. Longevity is easily over 12 hours or more.
This can be well suited for nightlife. Not a Raffaello for the beach, rather dark coconut with a lot of depth. Thanks to the coconut, it can be worn well on summer evenings/nights. For everyday wear, it's less suitable. Unisex is also fine, although it is significantly better received by men with 90% ownership. This is probably due to the bad-boy rum start. After about 2 hours, it becomes quite unisex.

Overall, a high-quality fragrance that can be well purchased on sale if you want a coconut-rum scent for the evening/night. Definitely worth testing before buying.

The sun high in the sky, the white sand so blazing hot.
In the comforting shade of a palm tree, somewhere in the South Sea - who knows?!

Leaning against the trunk, a pirate as drunk as can be.
In his left hand a jug of mojito, in the other a bottle with rum written on it.

Alternately he takes a sip, sometimes from the bottle, sometimes from the full jug.
With a cloudy gaze, he lights his cigar from Nicaragua and takes a deep drag.

How long he has been here, he does not know and does not want to know.
What he also does not know is when he had his last bite.

But with a thud against the trunk, a few coconuts fall down.
He indulges in them and is happy, as he no longer has to hunger.

He has everything he needs and feels like the king on his island.
Everything seems perfect - if only he didn’t have such a terrible burn.

But his mood lifts immediately at the sight of the chest made of light cedar.
Filled with gold ducats, jewelry of ancient Aztecs, some tonka, and bottles from a bodega.

Slowly, the dark sea and the red sun merge in a swirling symbiosis.
The pirate's gaze wanders longingly over the horizon and over the oak moss growing on the chest.

Fin.
______________________

Nishane's Fan Your Flames ranks quite high on my list of alcoholic fragrances, if not at the very top. This is probably because I have found a truly authentic "booze" scent in Fan Your Flames for the first time. Where other fragrances only use fewer facets of spirits, Nishane's creation offers the full spectrum of top-notch rum from the Caribbean. The aroma of the sugarcane schnapps develops a bit sharp and piercing right from the start and becomes increasingly softer, fuller, and almost reveals a fine sweetness as it progresses. Following this are smoky coconuts and light tobacco. The tobacco note indeed reminds one of hand-rolled cigars from Nicaragua, but the coconut note does not quite evoke images of fresh coconuts. Much more, the note recalls coconut-flavored rolling papers, which we smoked for a while in our youth - a lovely nostalgic feeling! Next, a bit of citrus and a hint of mint join the rum. With the very sugarcane-heavy rum, an aroma develops that strongly reminds one of refreshing mojitos. As it progresses, Fan Your Flames gains sweetness on one side, while on the other side, an increasingly intense cedar note emerges. The latter dominates the fragrance after the initial burst and gives it its sharp-woody character, which is underlaid by a bit of zesty oak moss.

So, if you are looking for an authentically alcoholic fragrance, you can certainly find it here - a feeling of the Caribbean is included!

The most important thing first: give it time! For me, nothing happened until about 20 minutes in. After spraying and even five minutes later, there was only a very subtle woody note and a faint hint of undefined sweetness. Boring. But the pirate ship crept closer, and suddenly the party started, with all the ingredients of a Caribbean party invited: coconut, rum, the pleasant...

review_title: Grandiose blend of Pina Colada and Caribbean beach
review_content:
As can be seen from many other reviews here, there is often talk of a pirate or even a "gentleman pirate."
This comparison is quite fitting - probably or especially because of the rum.
I would like to describe it differently.
Imagine you are on vacation. 10 days in the Caribbean, preferably Cuba.
You are lying on the beach. The typical vacation photo - turquoise blue water meets fine, white sand. There are countless palm trees on the beach.
In your wooden lounge chair, next to which stands a wooden sunshade with a thatched roof, you are enjoying a nice Pina Colada - of course authentically served in a coconut.
In your other hand, you have a real Cuban cigar.

You are enjoying the stress-free life before the vacation ends and you have to go back to work.

This scent really reminds me of a vacation in the Caribbean. I find the combination of coconut, tobacco, and rum really great.
I fell in love with the fragrance at the first sniff. I am glad that I stumbled upon it through a blind swap; otherwise, I would have really missed out.

Longevity and sillage are nishane typical and really extremely good. It easily exceeds 10 hours.

But beware: one to a maximum of 2 sprays are really enough.
The scent is truly ultra strong.
Almost overwhelming, but the coconut gives the fragrance a light note.
I personally never adhere to the conventions of "summer" and "winter," but I would tend to say that this is more of a scent for cold days.

However, I would also wear it in summer. The coconut and rum evoke the ultimate vacation feeling!

I personally find Fan Your Flames a bit tricky. At times it is beautiful but then again too cumbersome. Above all, there is an earthiness that I find disturbing. The longevity on my skin is quite successful at 8 to 10 hours, and I would also describe the sillage as good.

The top note starts off sweet with creamy coconut milk but is also very woody thanks to rum-soaked oak barrels. The heart note offers a lot of tobacco and a bit of tonka beans. Unfortunately, the base is too earthy and peaty for me. The oak moss bothers me quite a bit. There is also dark leather.

Unfortunately, there was no spark between me and "Fan Your Flames | Nishane." Nevertheless, I thank Niklas for the manufacturer sample.

I mean with this Nishane fragrance, apart from oak moss, I can actually perceive all the listed notes. An incredibly warm and very enveloping scent. Unobtrusive coconut, nicely vanilla, light tobacco, and a moderate alcoholic note with very good longevity... simply very well composed. I really like this spicy, subtly sweet progression. Now and then, a hint of sunscreen wafts into the nose, creating a kind of beach, vacation feeling. Traditionally, most connoisseurs would probably reserve 'Flames' for the cooler months, but I can’t help but occasionally spritz it over citrus notes even in summer.
Fan your Flames by Nishane is a perfume of excellent quality that is worth its price.

review_title: Rum and Tobacco - a combination I thought I knew by heart...
review_content:
A beautiful, fundamentally rather wintery tobacco and rum scent, which is made very special by the coconut. Somehow, the coconut does not fit this fragrance at all, yet still, or precisely because of that, I can't imagine the scent without this intriguingly interpreted note. I perceive the coconut very clearly throughout the entire scent development. Right at the beginning, it is rather fresh and by no means sweet. Anyone thinking of sunscreen or cocktails here is, in my opinion, mistaken... Rather, it resembles a realistic, somewhat unripe coconut that has been layered over the finished fragrance. It sounds a bit odd at first, but in the final product, it is incredibly beautiful. As the scent develops further, it becomes a bit sweeter, which is probably due to the tonka bean, without losing that realistic, unripe touch.

Nishane has impressively shown that they can play well with vanilla in Ani EXTRAIT DE PARFUM and "Ambra Calabria | Nishane." However, with Fan Your Flames, I am very glad that there is no vanilla included. This would have pushed the scent too much in a wintery direction... Instead, the fragrance creates a very fine balance between cozy warmth and an interesting tropical touch with the coconut.

Both the tobacco and rum smell very realistic and develop a sweet-bitter scent on my skin. The cedarwood gives the fragrance a bright, woody base and prevents it from going too strongly in the gourmand direction. With the fragrance pyramid in mind, I imagine that I can smell the oak moss, even though I actually don't know how it should smell on its own. I can generally pick out each of the listed components, which is rather rare for me.

Through other reviews and videos, I expected the scent to be smokier than it actually is on my skin. It strikes the perfect balance for me between boozy-sweet, woody, and fruity-bitter. This makes it very difficult for me to classify the perfume into a specific season. I wore it yesterday, carefully dosed, at 20 degrees and thoroughly enjoyed the scent trail. In my opinion, you can wear Fan Your Flames all year round, except for sunny summer days, although in deep winter, I would probably lean more towards sweeter alcoholic scents like "Side Effect | Initio."

Definitely a great fragrance that allows you to stand out from the crowd perfectly, without trying too hard to be noticed. The true magic reveals itself only when you wear the scent on your neck and perceive it through the fragrance cloud. Therefore, one should wear the fragrance, if possible, before evaluating it. The longevity on my skin is superb, the sillage is typically "subdued" and wave-like for an extrait, but just right for the scent. The bottle and packaging are quite impressive, and the overall picture simply works. One of the few fragrances in the niche segment where I feel that it is worth every cent, without having financed expensive marketing campaigns... So definitely give it a try! :)

Fan your Flames is the perfect winter fragrance that still has a tropical touch.
It starts with a strong rum and coconut note and later harmonizes with tobacco and a slightly sweet/spicy scent. In my opinion, after a few hours, you can also detect a cinnamon-like smell.
Overall, Fan your Flames is a journey that you must experience.

To be honest, I wasn't the biggest fan during the first wear, but over time I grew more fond of the scent. The probably most controversial point of the fragrance development is the opening, where the tobacco is very present and almost a bit ashy. The coconut also smelled a bit like toothpaste. However, you learn to differentiate and appreciate that after wearing it for a...

Since Nishane is a brand that seems very popular and I quickly fell deeply in love with "Ani (Extrait de Parfum) | Nishane," I wanted to test and learn more from this house.

In terms of quality, Nishane plays in a high league, which is not surprising since almost every fragrance is an extrait.

The bottles are quite simple. A square block with a label on the front and a nice heavy cap.
So, not really impressive in itself, but still it feels complete and somehow shines through its simplicity.

Now let’s finally get to the fragrance "Fan Your Flames | Nishane."
As mentioned above, I was shockingly in love with "Ani (Extrait de Parfum) | Nishane," and unfortunately, I was not as thrilled with "Fan Your Flames | Nishane."

At the start, a sweetness kisses the nose. This is realized through a distinct coconut note paired with a hint of rum and tobacco.
The coconut is the star at the beginning and projects very strongly and clearly, nicely rounded off by the rum.
Rum is definitely recognizable, but it doesn’t play the main role, and in the background, a hint of tobacco can be sensed.

I don’t know why I always associate it with "Replica - By the Fireplace | Maison Margiela," but somehow I picked up this phrase and, unfortunately, had a certain expectation.
With "Replica - By the Fireplace | Maison Margiela," it is not comparable at all, and I don’t find any similarity, which wouldn’t have been tragic if it still managed to shine.

After a while, the tonka bean joins in, and the fragrance becomes sweeter.
The tonka bean is also only perceptible far in the background and additionally supports the sweetness of the coconut with the other notes, rum and tobacco.

Over time, the coconut note fades more and more, and the rum and tonka bean shine through increasingly, becoming the main players.
Even though it sounds strange, at this stage it reminds me a lot of "Replica - Jazz Club | Maison Margiela," which is "okay" in my eyes.
Even "Replica - Jazz Club | Maison Margiela" didn’t evoke a "must-have" vibe in me.

A kind of roughness, as the name might suggest, I hardly perceive, which I actually find quite unfortunate.
So far, the naming and what you get is not quite fitting. At least for me and according to my perception.

Over time, moss and cedarwood notes shine through more and more, and I must say that the moss gives the fragrance a somewhat musty, earthy development.
In my opinion, it completely ruins the fragrance, and it evolves from "wow, that’s sweet" to "yeah, it’s okay" to "oh no, definitely not my thing" or "not at all!"

Because of the moss and cedarwood, which shine more and more at the end, it feels very musty and medicinal. It reminds me of a fragrance, but unfortunately, I can’t recall which one it could be (mine would be one from BDK)!

Most niche fragrances actually develop the other way around. At the beginning, either too much, too intense, or very strange (see "Musc Ravageur | Editions de Parfums Frédéric Malle") and develop into a delight and even a pleasure.
But this one does it exactly the opposite.
But what you have to give the fragrance is that it has a very recognizable development, even if in my eyes it is rather negative, but it is present, and thus the art is recognizable :-)

Very, very unfortunate!

Nevertheless, I am curious about what else the house has to offer and hope that they have a fragrance in their collection that makes me as shockingly in love as the wonderful "Ani (Extrait de Parfum) | Nishane."

The first spray takes me under a palm tree on the promenade in Havana. To my left, the crystal-clear sea and the white sandy beach. To my right, the brightly painted old buildings of the city.
The sky is blue and it’s 36 degrees, a light breeze is blowing that cools my skin. A vendor is selling fresh coconuts at his street stand not far from me.
I have a Montecristo in one hand and a 25-year-old Ron Vacilón in the other. Now and then, an old Cadillac drives by. Satisfaction and inner peace spread within me.
Life can be so beautiful.
A wonderfully sweet coconut rum scent!

review_title: The Alcoholized Coconut with a Hint of Vanilla is Fighting for Me!!
review_content:
The scent starts with a chord of coconut and plenty of alcohol. I feel transported to a warm South Sea beach with a rum-coconut cocktail in hand. Right next to me, two women are vying for my attention. Both want to go out with me tonight. But only one can win. The fire of passion is evident in the battle between rum and coconut. Both engage in a fiery duel. From time to time, they are supported by tobacco and tonka bean. So who has won? In my opinion, it’s the rum. It makes the coconut drunk and kicks it out of the ring.
Now it gets more sensual… Oakmoss and cedar give the scent a touch of elegant woodiness in the drydown.

All in all, a very good scent for an evening out to dinner or to the club.
The sillage and longevity are beastly. The longevity for me was over 10 hours. Still noticeable on clothing days later.

Are you looking for a good boozy scent? One that also has a nice rum note?
Then off you go to test it!!

I have come to know a few perfumes that smell of ash and fire - burnt and hot - through some samples, and I have now acquired several of this kind.

Fan Your Flames is one of them - and I must say at this point that I personally find this scent simply incredible.

Initially strongly smoky, fresh from the sprayer, the scent is somewhat of an acquired taste, and it takes a while for it to develop on my skin. However, then coconut and tonka come to the fore, mixed with the wood and the strong rum note that runs through the entire fragrance, making it a bit sweeter - I would almost say pleasing, even though I know that this type of scent is not for everyone.

The longevity is brutal on my skin. It easily lasts all day, and the sillage is - sometimes to the lament of those around me - also very, very good - but since this is my current favorite scent, I admit that I sometimes apply it quite heavily.

A fragrance, a bit like a dwarf tavern. Smoky, tobacco-heavy... and the strong alcohol first... but still, one is tempted to sit down on old wooden benches next to the fire - to order a strong schnapps and some sweet cakes from the somewhat grim, tough innkeeper.

Those who thought coconut and rum could only evoke beach vacations have yet to smell "Fan Your Flames | Nishane." Nishane transforms these ingredients into a smoky spectacle - half cigar lounge, half burning wooden barrel. The coconut? Not fresh and sweet, but smoky, slightly tipsy, and kissed by fire - as if it had lingered too long next to the embers and started to...

review_title: A special scent that somehow captivates. Campfire + Pina Colada? YES!
review_content:
Fan Your Flames is a truly unique fragrance. It combines Pina Colada vibes with a campfire.

Imagine sitting in the garden with friends in the evening by a wonderful campfire.
You pour some rum into the fire to make the flames even bigger, and you also toss in some coconut flakes and a few tonka beans.
Meanwhile, you're smoking a cigarette.
That's Fan Your Flames!

Sounds crazy, is crazy, but there's something really interesting about it.
I personally find the scent really cool. It stands out from others and combines so many things at once.

This fragrance works excellently on cold days, but also in summer.
You could tell the story differently.

You're on vacation in the Caribbean with your friends. In the evening, you're sitting on the beach, looking at the sea, one is smoking a cigarette, another a cigar, and another a cigarillo, while you all sip a strong Pina Colada that blows you away.

Yeah, yeah... this scent is fun.
The longevity and sillage are also quite impressive.
You'll get a lot out of this.

Definitely worth a try.

review_title: Is it too strong, are you too weak | Risk of Overwhelm for Untrained Noses; with Risks and Side Effects
review_content:
The Fan Your Flames was one of my first niche fragrances, and I believe that was my biggest mistake with this scent. After applying it twice, I sold it again; it was too strong for me, smelled too angular and edgy, almost cloyingly sweet-alcoholic, simply unpleasant.

This week I tested the Fan Your Flames again, a few years and hundreds of fragrances later, and yes, I must say; the Fan Your Flames is truly special and above all, quite good!

Now to the Fan Your Flames - how does it smell?
- I believe that the opening can still be a slight challenge for many even after years of perfume experience. You get a real blast of coconut-rum, this combo is extremely high dosed and strong upon spraying. The first 5 minutes were still challenging for me, but not unpleasant. It is simply strong and edgy!

- After 5-15 minutes, this extremely strong combo settles down, and a beautiful tobacco note slowly joins in, giving the fragrance a slight spiciness and balancing out the sweetness of the coconut a bit. Now it starts to get exciting and beautiful. In the drydown, it then receives the typical Nishane oakmoss base, of course not as strong as in Hacivat, since the coconut-rum note carries through to the drydown, but the sweetness gradually recedes, and you get a beautiful melange of coconut-rum-tobacco-oakmoss, perfectly balanced.

- The longevity of this fragrance is truly beastly; it doesn’t run out of steam for a very long time! The sillage is definitely in the upper third; the fragrance projects and projects!

Overall, a fragrance for which you really have to be ready. It is special, yes, representing a coconut in such an alcoholic-spicy way is not typical, as coconut often finds its way into fresher scents, but if you have enough experience and give the fragrance a little time, it could indeed become a good companion for special occasions!

Boozy Sweety Scent,
My beginning with the fragrance was very nice, as I received a sample, and because I am a fan of the coconut note combined with the boozy blend represented here, I later bought a whole bottle at a very affordable price.

The scent is a fiery ball with an opening of coconut and rum, featuring notes of tobacco and the sweet taste of tonka bean with oak moss and wood.

Honestly, I found this perfume very boring after several applications.
The fragrance combination is unbalanced here, and too much spray causes headaches.
There is a synthetic smell that I only recognized after longer use of the perfume; the scent of coconut is like an unripe fruit that is still green and has a thick shell.

The fragrance notes will fascinate those who haven’t tried it, especially for those who love coconut, but anyone who has tried Creed Virgin Island Water will likely discard this perfume.
Creed created a summery scent, in contrast to Fan Your Flames as a winter fragrance.

And the perfume rightly bears its name, as it truly makes one feel indescribably warm on the harshest cold days, because the hot notes "tobacco, coconut, rum" are mixed in an innovative and unique way.

The performance of the perfume is very good; it lasts for two hours, with a longevity of over 12 hours on the skin and on clothing for weeks.

review_title: All the Delights of the Tropics
review_content:
Television advertising has changed dramatically over the last 40 years. Who doesn't remember (if they are of the appropriate age) the cute little Clementine, the Persil uncle, or Mr. Kaiser? And the ad for my (then and now) favorite chocolate bar has certainly stuck in my mind. The coconut/chocolate bomb was advertised back then with the - at first glance grammatically peculiar - slogan "All the Delights of the Tropics".
That this at least has its justification in the GERMAN language should be clear to everyone by now; but whether one can/should/must evaluate the "tropics" solely based on a sweet treat is open to doubt.
Yes, I am a fan of coconuts! That’s why I am always on the hunt for fragrances that evoke a corresponding association in me. "Fan your Flames" - ignite your flames, is the name of this fantastic product from the equally fantastic Turkish brand NISHANE. And yes, it ignites in me the memory of a hearty bite into the sweet something that has been haunting me since my childhood. However, this memory is more mature; more robust. A slight rum note accompanies the opening, without one being bothered by a fusel smell. The experience also becomes slightly woodier over the course of the - well 10 hours of longevity. The initial perception and thus the journey into the "Bounty childhood" remains ever-present for me, yet the rum/tobacco mix prevails here. The sillage is okay, though not overwhelming. And that's a good thing, as not everyone is a fan of the Caribbean faction. Compared to my other highlight in this fragrance category Virgin Island Water, "FYF" performs significantly spicier. However, the longevity is also significantly better. Do we still need to talk about the price of Nishane fragrances? I don't think so… But there really isn't a true alternative if you want to experience a somewhat authentic feeling…
Love it!

Since I am an absolute fan of the Nishane label, I had to buy and test Fan Your Flames, of course. No front, I find it to be the weakest among the Nishane candidates so far. The ingredients sounded very good with the reviews, so I had a rough idea of which direction it was going. The opening in the first minutes gives me a strange impression .. You can clearly perceive...

review_title: Consistently dry-woody tobacco scent with a touch of tropics
review_content:
A coconut with a lot of grass and dry tobacco makes its presence felt right from the start; I’ve rarely experienced such a dry coconut, as it usually turns creamy and kitschy quickly. It’s a different way to stage the notes directly in the head.
To be honest, I felt very little rum in the top notes; tobacco and coconut were rather upfront, and the former quickly takes over more after 10-15 minutes. One of the woodiest interpretations of tobacco I know, it sometimes feels more like finely worked fresh wood than actual tobacco leaves or even that sweet pipe tobacco note that one sometimes encounters. I guess it’s the cedar in the base that is already shining through in parts and exerting influence.

The transition to the even woodier and slightly forest-dry base is particularly nice and smooth; this tobacco-cedar main combination with light, dry moss notes lasts very long and consistently.

Overall, it’s not particularly varied, but a very well-balanced tobacco-wood scent with a hint of tropics, and rum is rather minimal to nonexistent for me.

[tested on skin]

I was eagerly waiting for the sample to arrive, and today it came… The scent starts with quite smoky woods, almost burnt. Initially a bit of an acquired taste, but after about half an hour, the fragrance really takes off. The burnt woody notes recede, and the coconut and tobacco emerge, followed by a hint of rum.

Longevity is above average. Additionally, the scent develops into a sweet direction, although it seems quite different at first. The fragrance is more suitable for milder seasons. I definitely categorize this scent as masculine, less so for a lady.

In comparison to Jazz Club, which I also own… although the fragrance notes are similar, I find that the scents are quite different. In my opinion, the coconut is a bit more present in the top note of Jazz Club, even though there is no coconut in it at all, very strange.

Back to Nishane Fan Your Flame. I find it well done, although everyone perceives the fragrance notes differently. For some, the rum note or the coconut is less present, even though the fragrance notes come across very well. Yes, the rum could have been a tad stronger, but otherwise, everything is detectable. As for the coconut… it is not as artificial as in shampoos but rather kept natural.

For those with the necessary funds, I would prefer Jazz Club here because the sillage and longevity are significantly better.

review_title: great scent that gave me a headache at first
review_content: The scent itself is not bad, but there is something in it that gave me a headache at first. The typical Nishane DNA is immediately noticeable, along with something synthetic. The coconut is still green, and I also smell something mossy! As much as I was looking forward to the scent and I really like the ingredients, I can't wear this too often. The first 2 hours are fine, but...

At the opening of "Fan Your Flames | Nishane," one gets the impression of being in a bar. On the wooden tables around, only one spirit is being consumed: rum
Not mixed with sweet, sticky cocktails, but neat, authentic.
From the adjacent smoking room, a subtle, smoky nuance seeps through the closed door. It wafts into the bar unobtrusively, carrying a hint of coconut with it, which it picked up from the only person in the whole room who is drinking Pina Colada with fresh coconut instead of rum.

This is roughly how I perceive "Fan Your Flames | Nishane." The rum note is clearly dominant, but it is by no means unpleasant or too alcoholic. Rather warm and boozy.
I perceive the smoke and coconut in the background, but they are slightly overshadowed by the woody notes of oak moss and sourwood.

A wonderfully crafted fragrance, which, however, due to the very prominent rum note for me is not a candidate for purchase. A candidate for purchase is also not Angels' Share EAU DE PARFUM for cognac reasons, and it rightfully has an enormous fan base.

So just test it and let yourself be enchanted.
